whether the registrant (1) has filed all reports required to be filed by

contained herein, and will not be contained, to the best of registrant&#146;s

whether the registrant is a large accelerated filer, an accelerated filer, or a
non-accelerated filer. See definition of &#147;accelerated filer and large
accelerated filer&#148; in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange Act. (Check one):</font></b></p>

  </td>
  <td width="32%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.0%;">
  <p align="center" style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Accelerated
  filer&nbsp;</font><font face="Wingdings">x</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.98%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="32%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.0%;">
  <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Non-accelerated filer&nbsp;</font><font face="Wingdings">o</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p align="left" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;margin:12.0pt 0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:13.5pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">Indicate by check mark whether
the registrant is a shell company (as defined in Rule 12b-2 of the Exchange
Act). Yes&nbsp;&nbsp;</font></b><font face="Wingdings" style="font-weight:normal;">o</font><font style="font-weight:normal;">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No&nbsp;&nbsp;</font><font face="Wingdings" style="font-weight:normal;">x</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:13.5pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">The aggregate market value
of the voting stock held by non-affiliates of the registrant as of June 30,
2006 was $49 million.</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:13.5pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">As of January 31, 2007,
there were 87,381,308 shares of the registrant&#146;s Common Stock outstanding.</font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">DOCUMENTS INCORPORATED BY REFERENCE</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:13.7pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain information required to be included in Part III of this Form
10-K will be provided in accordance with General Instruction G3 no later than
April 30, 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <div style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 6.0pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;"> <p style="border:none;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;padding:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p> </div>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='',FILE='C:\Fc\74121146591_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-ba.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:11 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p align="center" style="line-height:12.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART I</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 1.</font></b>&#160; <b>BUSINESS</b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest Airlines Corporation (&#147;NWA Corp.&#148;
and, together with its subsidiaries, the &#147;Company&#148;) is the indirect parent
corporation of Northwest Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Northwest&#148;).&#160; Unless otherwise indicated, the terms &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us,&#148;
and &#147;our&#148; refer to NWA Corp. and all consolidated subsidiaries.&#160; Northwest operates the world&#146;s sixth largest
airline, as measured by 2006 revenue passenger miles (&#147;RPMs&#148;), and is engaged
in the business of transporting passengers and cargo.&#160; Northwest began operations in 1926.&#160; Northwest&#146;s business focuses on the operation
of a global airline network through its strategic assets that include:</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>domestic hubs at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul
and Memphis;</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>an extensive Pacific route system with a hub
in Tokyo;</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>a transatlantic joint venture with KLM Royal
Dutch Airlines (&#147;KLM&#148;), which operates through a hub in Amsterdam;</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>a domestic and international alliance with
Continental Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Continental&#148;) and Delta Air Lines, Inc. (&#147;Delta&#148;);</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>membership in SkyTeam, a global airline
alliance with KLM, Continental, Delta, Air France, Alitalia, Aerom&#233;xico, CSA
Czech Airlines, Korean Air and Aeroflot;</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>agreements with three domestic regional
carriers, including Pinnacle Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Pinnacle Airlines&#148;) and Mesaba
Aviation, Inc. (&#147;Mesaba&#148;), each of which operates as Northwest Airlink, and
Compass Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Compass&#148;), a wholly-owned subsidiary, which will
operate as a Northwest Airlink carrier;</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:-18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>a cargo business that operates a dedicated
freighter fleet of aircraft through hubs in Anchorage and Tokyo.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest&#146;s business strategies are designed
to utilize these assets to the Company&#146;s competitive advantage.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company maintains a Web site at <i>http://www.nwa.com</i>.&#160; Information contained on the Company&#146;s Web
site is not incorporated into this annual report on Form 10-K.&#160; Annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly
reports on Form 10-Q, current reports on Form 8-K, all amendments to those
reports and other information about the Company are available free of charge through
its Web site at <i>http://ir.nwa.com</i>
as soon as reasonably practicable after those reports are electronically filed
with or furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;).&#160; For information or questions concerning the
Company&#146;s Chapter 11 restructuring see: <i>http://www.nwa-restructuring.com</i>.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">See &#147;Item 1A. Risk Factors&#148; and &#147;Item 7.
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations &#151; Overview&#148; for a discussion of trends and factors affecting the
Company and the airline industry.&#160; The
Company is managed as one cohesive business unit, but employs various
strategies specific to the geographic regions in which it operates.&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial
Statements and Supplementary Data, Note 19 &#151; Geographic Regions&#148; for a
discussion of Northwest&#146;s operations by geographic region.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Chapter
11 Proceedings</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On September 14, 2005 (the &#147;Petition Date&#148;),
NWA Corp. and 12 of its direct and indirect subsidiaries (collectively, the &#147;Debtors&#148;)
filed voluntary petitions for relief under Chapter 11 of the United States
Bankruptcy Code with the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern
District of New York (the &#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;).&#160;
Subsequently, on September 30, 2005, NWA Aircraft Finance, Inc., an
indirect subsidiary of NWA Corp., also filed a voluntary petition for relief
under Chapter 11.&#160; The Bankruptcy Court
is jointly administering these cases under the caption &#147;In re Northwest
Airlines Corporation, et al., Case No. 05-17930 (ALG)&#148; (the &#147;Chapter 11 case&#148;).&#160; Accordingly, the accompanying consolidated
financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the American
Institute of Certified Public Accountants Statement of Position 90-7, <i>Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization
under the Bankruptcy</i>  <i>Code </i>(&#147;SOP
90-7&#148;)<i>,</i> and on a going concern
basis, which contemplates continuity of operations, realization of assets and
liquidation of post-petition liabilities in the ordinary course of
business.&#160; In accordance with SOP 90-7,
the financial statements for the periods presented distinguish transactions and
events that are directly associated with the reorganization from the ongoing
operations of the Company.&#160; The
consolidated financial statements shown herein include certain subsidiaries
that did not file to reorganize under Chapter 11.&#160; The assets and liabilities of these
subsidiaries are not considered material to the consolidated financial
statements.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Due to our Chapter 11 proceedings, the
realization of assets and the satisfaction of liabilities, without substantial
adjustments and/or changes in ownership, are subject to uncertainty, and
accordingly, there is substantial doubt about the current financial reporting
entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern.&#160; Upon emergence from bankruptcy, we expect to adopt
fresh start reporting in accordance with SOP 90-7 which will result in our
becoming a new entity for financial reporting purposes.&#160; The adoption of fresh start reporting will
have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements of the new financial
reporting entity.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Plan of Reorganization. </font></i>&#160;On January 12, 2007, NWA Corp. and thirteen of
its direct and indirect subsidiaries, including Northwest, filed with the
Bankruptcy Court the Debtors&#146; Joint and Consolidated Plan of Reorganization
Under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; On January 12, 2007, the Bankruptcy
Court granted the Company an extension until February 15, 2007 to file the
related Disclosure Statement with respect to Debtors&#146; Joint and Consolidated
Plan of Reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (&#147;Disclosure
Statement&#148;).&nbsp; Subsequently, on February 15, 2007, the Company filed its
Disclosure Statement and the First Amended Joint and Consolidated Plan of
Reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code (the &#147;Plan&#148; or &#147;Plan of
Reorganization&#148;).&#160; Copies of the Plan and
the Disclosure Statement were attached as Exhibits 99.2 and 99.3, respectively,
to our Current Report on Form 8-K dated February 16, 2007.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On March 2, 2007, the Company filed a motion
with the Bankruptcy Court, requesting that its exclusivity period for filing a
reorganization plan be extended to June 29, 2007.&#160; During the exclusivity period, which is
currently set to expire March 16, 2007, only the Company can propose a
reorganization plan.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Plan provides for the treatment of claims
of creditors, the implementation of agreements with key labor groups, lenders,
and suppliers, as well as the raising of new equity capital by NWA Corp.&#160; The Plan proposes to restructure the Company&#146;s
balance sheet through the elimination of all pre-petition unsecured debt.&nbsp;
In exchange for their allowed claims, unsecured creditors will receive Common
Stock of the reorganized NWA Corp. and the right to purchase additional Common
Stock in a rights offering. Because all unsecured creditor claims will not be
satisfied in full, the pre-petition equity holders&#146; interests in NWA Corp.&#146;s
Common and Preferred Stock will be cancelled, and those holders will not
receive a distribution.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A hearing on the adequacy of information in
the Disclosure Statement is scheduled for March 26, 2007.&#160; After approval by the Bankruptcy Court, the
Company will distribute the Plan and Disclosure Statement to its creditors and
begin a period of solicitation of creditors for acceptance of the Plan.&#160; The Disclosure Statement contains detailed
information about the Plan, the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order approving the
Disclosure Statement, notice of the time for filing acceptance or rejection of
the Plan and timing of the hearing to consider confirmation of the Plan, the
rights offering, financial projections and financial estimates regarding the
Debtors&#146; reorganized business enterprise value. The information contained in
the Disclosure Statement is subject to change, whether as a result of
amendments to the Plan, actions of third parties or otherwise.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Nothing contained in this Form 10-K is
intended to be, nor should it be construed as, a solicitation for a vote on the
Plan. The Plan will become effective only if it receives the requisite approval
and is confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court, which the Company currently expects
to occur during the second quarter of 2007.&#160;
However, there can be no assurance that the Bankruptcy Court will
confirm the Plan or that the Plan will be implemented successfully.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Restructuring Goals</font></i>.&#160; The
Company identified three major elements essential to transforming its business
and has substantially completed the actions necessary to achieve its targeted
business improvements.&#160; The three major
elements included:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Achieving approximately $2.4 billion in annual cost reductions,
including both labor and non-labor costs;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Resizing and optimization of the Company&#146;s fleet to better serve
Northwest&#146;s markets;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Restructuring and recapitalization of the Company&#146;s balance sheet,
including a targeted reduction in debt and lease obligations of approximately
$4.2 billion, providing debt and equity levels consistent with long-term
profitability.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company used the provisions of Chapter 11
and other changes implemented in its business to achieve its targeted
restructuring improvements.&#160; Outlined
below is an overview of significant transactions related to labor and non-labor
cost restructuring, fleet optimization, and the Company&#146;s balance sheet
restructuring efforts.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Labor Cost Restructuring.&#160; </font></i>The Company has ratified
collective bargaining agreements (&#147;CBAs&#148;) or implemented contractual terms and
conditions which collectively provide for approximately $1.4 billion in annual
labor cost savings.&#160; The Company has
reached consensual agreement on CBAs with the Air Line Pilots Association (&#147;ALPA&#148;),
the International Association of
Machinists and Aerospace Workers (&#147;IAM&#148;), the Aircraft Technical Support
Association (&#147;ATSA&#148;), the Transport Workers Union of America (&#147;TWU&#148;), and the
Northwest Airlines Meteorologists Association (&#147;NAMA&#148;).&#160; The agreements with ALPA, the IAM, ATSA, TWU,
and NAMA were implemented on or before August 1, 2006.&#160; Two rounds of salaried and management
employee pay and benefit cuts have also been achieved and implemented.&#160;&#160; In addition, the Company imposed contract
terms on its technicians represented by the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal
Association (&#147;AMFA&#148;) in August 2005 and, under Section 1113(c) of the
Bankruptcy Code, imposed contract terms on its flight attendants represented by
the Association of Flight Attendants-Communication Workers of America (&#147;AFA-CWA&#148;)
on July 31, 2006.&#160; On November 6, 2006,
the Company reached a ratified agreement with AMFA to end the labor dispute
with the airline&#146;s technicians.&#160; The
agreement maintains the necessary annual labor cost savings from
AMFA-represented employees.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Section 1113(c) of the Bankruptcy Code permits a
debtor to move to reject its CBAs if the debtor first satisfies a number of
statutorily prescribed substantive and procedural prerequisites and obtains the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s approval of the rejection or the expiration of the
statutorily prescribed time period.&#160;
After bargaining in good faith and sharing relevant information with its
unions, a debtor must make proposals to modify its existing CBAs based on the
most complete and reliable information available at the time.&#160; The proposed modifications must be necessary
to permit the reorganization of a debtor and must provide that all the affected
parties are treated fairly and equitably.&#160;
Ultimately, rejection of the CBAs is appropriate if the unions refuse to
agree to a debtor&#146;s necessary proposal &#147;without good cause&#148; and the Bankruptcy
Court determines that the balance of the equities favors rejection.&#160;&#160; In October 2005, the Company commenced
Section 1113(c) proceedings with ALPA, the IAM and the Professional Flight
Attendants Association (&#147;PFAA&#148;) and has subsequently reached consensual
agreement with ALPA and the IAM.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With respect to the Company&#146;s flight attendants, the
Company reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with its flight
attendants represented by the PFAA on March 1, 2006 (the &#147;March TA&#148;).&#160; On June 6, 2006, the PFAA announced that the
flight attendants failed to ratify the tentative agreement.&#160; As a result of the flight attendants&#146; failure
to ratify this agreement, the Company requested a ruling from the Bankruptcy
Court on its Section 1113(c) motion to reject its existing flight attendant
labor agreement and to permit the Company to impose new contract terms.&#160; On June 29, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court
granted the Company&#146;s Section 1113(c) motion to reject its contract with the
flight attendants and authorized the Company to implement the terms of the
March TA; however, the Bankruptcy Court stayed implementation of the order
until July 17, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s June 29, 2006
ruling, the Company and the PFAA commenced negotiations to reach a new
agreement.&#160; On July 6, 2006, the Company&#146;s
flight attendants voted to change their union representation from the PFAA to
the AFA-CWA.&#160; Subsequently, the Company
and the AFA-CWA continued negotiations to reach a new agreement, and on July
17, 2006, the parties announced that they reached a new tentative agreement
(the &#147;July TA&#148;).&#160; On July 31, 2006, the
AFA-CWA announced that its members failed to approve the July TA.&#160; As a result of the flight attendants&#146; failure
to ratify the July TA, and in accordance with the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s previous
authorization, effective July 31, 2006 the Company implemented new contract
terms and conditions for its flight attendants, consistent with the terms and
conditions of the March TA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On
July 31, 2006, following the flight attendants&#146; failure to ratify a second
proposed CBA and the Company&#146;s subsequent imposition of new contract terms for
the flight attendants, the AFA-CWA provided the Company with a 15-day notice of
its intent to strike or engage in other work actions, including CHAOS (Create
Havoc Around Our System).&#160; In response,
on August 1, 2006, the Company filed a motion with the Bankruptcy Court seeking
to obtain an injunction against such activities.&#160; The AFA-CWA subsequently extended the strike
deadline by 10 days to August 25, 2006, in response to terrorist threats
against air travel to and within the United States.&#160; On August 17, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court
denied the Company&#146;s request for an injunction.&#160;
On August 18, 2006, the Company filed an appeal of the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s
decision with the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York (&#147;U.S. District Court&#148;). On August 25, 2006, the U.S. District Court
issued an injunction pending appeal which temporarily prevented any work action
by the AFA-CWA while the court considered the Company&#146;s appeal.&#160; The U.S. District Court reversed the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on September 15, 2006, and granted the Company&#146;s
request for a preliminary injunction to prevent a threatened strike or work
action by the AFA-CWA.&#160; Subsequently, the
AFA-CWA appealed the U.S. District Court&#146;s ruling to the U.S. Second Circuit
Court of Appeals.&#160; Arguments related to
this matter were heard on November 28, 2006 and the appeal is pending.&#160; In addition, the Company is currently in
mediated negotiations with the AFA-CWA and representatives of the National
Mediation Board (&#147;NMB&#148;).&#160; The AFA-CWA has
requested that it be released from further negotiations by the NMB; to date the
NMB has not granted this request.&#160;&#160; A
strike or other form of self-help could have a material adverse effect on the
Company.&#160; In addition, if the Company
does not achieve the targeted level of savings under a flight attendant
agreement, the amount of labor savings achieved through its other ratified CBAs
would be subject to reduction.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February 12, 2007, the
AFA-CWA filed a motion with the Bankruptcy Court seeking reconsideration of the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision to grant the Debtors&#146; Section 1113(c) motion to
reject the Debtors&#146; CBA with the flight attendants. The Debtors believe the
motion is without merit and will oppose the AFA-CWA&#146;s motion in the Bankruptcy
Court.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has also commenced proceedings under Section 1114 of the
Bankruptcy Code, pursuant to which the Company is seeking reductions in the
costs it incurs to provide medical benefits to retirees.&#160; Negotiations with the committee formed to
represent the Company&#146;s retirees are ongoing.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Non-labor Cost Restructuring</font></i>.&#160; The
Company continues to pursue reductions in non-labor costs consistent with its
current target of $350 million in annual savings.&#160; The Company expects to realize such savings
through restructured agreements with our regional airline affiliates, reduction
in properties and facilities costs, reduced fuel burn, lower distribution,
insurance and interest costs and optimization of other contractual
relationships.&#160; The Company estimates it
has realized approximately $100 million of the targeted savings in 2006, with
the majority of the remaining savings expected to be realized in 2007.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Fleet Optimization.&#160;
</font></i>The Company
right-sized and re-optimized its fleet and network by reducing system-wide
capacity by 9.2 percent during the first year in bankruptcy.&#160; For the full year 2006, the Company reduced
its system-wide consolidated available seat miles by 7.5 percent.&#160; The Company also reached new agreements and
affirmed existing&#160; arrangements on new
aircraft as part of its fleet optimization.&#160;
The Company affirmed its deliveries of Airbus A330 aircraft and now has
one of the youngest transatlantic fleets in the industry.&#160; The Company also affirmed its position as the
North American service launch airline of the new Boeing 787 with deliveries
beginning in August 2008, and ordered 72 76-seat regional jets that will be
introduced in 2007.&#160; The dual class
regional jets are optimally sized for many domestic markets and will give the
Company potential growth opportunities over time.&#160; In addition, the Company accelerated the
retirement of the DC10 and Boeing 747-200 wide-body aircraft as well as the
Avro RJ85 fleet.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Balance Sheet Restructuring</font></i>.&#160; Under the Plan, the Company
will reduce its total pre-petition debt by approximately $4.2 billion through
the elimination of unsecured debt and restructuring of aircraft and other
secured obligations.&#160; Additionally, the
Company refinanced its Bank Term Loan with the DIP/Exit financing facility,
providing a significant interest expense savings.&#160; The aircraft restructurings will result in an
estimated $400 million reduction in ownership costs including interest, rent
and depreciation expense.&#160; The
elimination of the unsecured debt will drive an additional interest expense
reduction of approximately $150 million annually.&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial
Statements and Supplementary Data, Note 6 &#151; Liabilities Subject to Compromise&#148;
for additional information.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General Bankruptcy Matters. </font></i>&#160;As
required by the Bankruptcy Code, the United States Trustee for the Southern
District of New York appointed on September 30, 2005 an Official Committee of
Unsecured Creditors (the &#147;Creditors&#146; Committee&#148;).&#160; The Creditors&#146; Committee and its legal
representatives have a right to be heard on all matters that come before the
Bankruptcy Court concerning the reorganization.&#160;
There can be no assurance that the Creditors&#146; Committee will support the
Company&#146;s positions or plan of reorganization.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With the exception of the Company&#146;s non-debtor subsidiaries, the Company
continues to operate its business as &#147;debtor-in-possession&#148; under the
jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy Court and in accordance with the applicable
provisions of the Bankruptcy Code, the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure
and applicable court orders.&#160; In general,
as debtor-in-possession, the Company is authorized under Chapter 11 to continue
to operate as an ongoing business, but may not engage in transactions outside
the ordinary course of business without the prior approval of the Bankruptcy
Court.&#160; In conjunction with the
commencement of the Chapter 11 case, the Debtors obtained several orders from
the Bankruptcy Court that were intended to enable the Debtors to operate in the
normal course of business during the Chapter 11 case.&#160; The most significant of these orders (i)
authorize the Company to honor pre-petition obligations to customers, (ii)
authorize the Company to honor obligations to employees for pre-petition
employee salaries, wages, incentive compensation and benefits, and (iii) permit
the Debtors to operate their consolidated cash management system during the
Chapter 11 case in substantially the same manner as it was operated prior to
the commencement of the Chapter 11 case.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The bankruptcy filing triggered defaults on substantially all the Company&#146;s
debt and lease obligations.&#160; Under
Section 362 of the Bankruptcy Code, the filing of a bankruptcy petition
automatically stays most actions against a debtor, including most actions to
collect pre-petition indebtedness or to exercise control over the property of a
debtor&#146;s estate.&#160; Absent an order of the
Bankruptcy Court, substantially all pre-petition liabilities are subject to
settlement under the plan of reorganization.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Debtors have endeavored to notify all of their known or potential
creditors whose claims are subject to the Chapter 11 case.&#160; Subject to certain exceptions under the
Bankruptcy Code, the Chapter 11 filings automatically stayed the continuation
of any judicial or administrative proceedings or other actions against the
Debtors or their property to recover on, collect or secure a claim arising
prior to the time of filing on September 14, 2005.&#160; The deadline for creditors to file proofs of
claim with the Bankruptcy Court (the &#147;Bar Date&#148;) was August 16, 2006.&#160; A proof of claim arising from the rejection
of an executory contract must be filed the later of the Bar Date or 30 days
from the effective date of the authorized rejection.&#160; As of December 31, 2006, the dollar amount of
all claims filed against the Debtors, as reflected on the claims register,
totaled approximately $129 billion. Differences in amount between claims filed
by creditors and liabilities shown in our records continue to be investigated
and resolved in connection with our claims resolution process. The Debtors
believe that many of these claims are subject to objection as being
duplicative, overstated, based upon contingencies that have not occurred, or
because they otherwise do not state a valid claim.&#160; The foregoing amount does not include claims
that were filed without a specified dollar amount, referred to as unliquidated
claims, and claims that were filed after the Bar Date.&#160; While significant progress has been made to
date, the Debtors are still in the process of resolving claims in accordance
with the claims resolution procedures approved by the Court; however,
completion of this process will likely occur well after confirmation of the
Debtors&#146; Plan.&#160; The Debtors believe that
the aggregate dollar amount of unsecured claims currently appearing on the
claims register far exceeds the total dollar amount of unsecured claims that
will ultimately be allowed against the Debtors in the cases.&#160; Although the ultimate dollar amount of such
claims is not known at this time, the Debtors estimate that the amount of
unsecured claims will be in the range of $8.75 billion to $9.5 billion.&#160; This estimate is subject to significant
uncertainties relating to the resolution of various claims, including the
resolution of contingent and unliquidated claims such as litigation.&#160; As a result, there can be no assurance that
the ultimate amount of such allowed claims will not exceed $9.5 billion.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Debtors have recorded liability amounts
for the claims that can be reasonably estimated and which we believe are
probable of being allowed by the Bankruptcy Court, and we have classified these
as liabilities subject to compromise in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.&#160;&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial
Statements and Supplementary Data, Note 6 &#151; Liabilities Subject to Compromise&#148;
for additional information.&#160; The Company
expects that additional liabilities subject to compromise will arise in the
future as a result of damage claims resulting from the rejection of certain
executory contracts and unexpired leases by the Debtors.&#160; However, the Company expects that the
assumption of certain executory contracts and unexpired leases may convert
liabilities subject to compromise to liabilities not subject to
compromise.&#160; In addition, other claims
may be recorded as a result of the Debtors claims resolution process.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Securities
Trading Matters.&#160; </font></i>On October 28, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
entered an order that restricts the trading of the Common Stock and debt
interests in the Company.&#160; The purpose of
the order is to ensure that the Company does not lose the benefit of its net
operating loss carryforwards (&#147;NOLs&#148;) for tax purposes.&#160; Under federal and state income tax law, NOLs
can be used to offset future taxable income, and thus are a valuable asset of
the Debtors&#146; estate.&#160; Certain trading in
the Company&#146;s stock (or debt when the Company is in bankruptcy) could adversely
affect the Company&#146;s ability to use the NOLs.&#160;
Thus, the Company obtained an order that enables it to closely monitor
certain transfers of stock and claims and restrict those transfers that may
compromise the Company&#146;s ability to use its NOLs.&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial
Statements and Supplementary Data, Note 12 &#151; Income Taxes&#148; for further
information related to the Company&#146;s NOLs.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Common Stock ceased trading on the NASDAQ stock market on
September 26, 2005 and now trades in the &#147;over-the-counter&#148; market under the
symbol NWACQ.PK.&#160; However, under the
Company&#146;s Plan, no value is ascribed to the Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock,
Preferred Stock or other equity securities.&#160;
Upon the effective date of the Plan, the outstanding Common and
Preferred Stock of the Company will be cancelled for no consideration and
therefore the Company&#146;s stockholders will no longer have any interest as
stockholders in the Company by virtue of their ownership of the Company&#146;s
Common or Preferred Stock prior to emergence from bankruptcy.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The New York Stock Exchange advised the
Company on September 15, 2005 that trading in Northwest&#146;s 10.5% Class D Pass
Through Certificates, Series 2003-1 due April 1, 2009, ticker symbol NWB RP09,
as well as the 9.5% Senior Quarterly Interest Bonds due August 15, 2039
(QUIBS), ticker symbol NWB, was suspended.&#160;
The QUIBS can still be traded on the &#147;over-the-counter&#148; market under the
symbol NWBBQ.PK; however, the Company is no longer accruing or paying interest.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Request for
Equity Committee.&#160; </font></i>On or about November 22, 2006, certain equity
holders of the Debtors requested, by letter, that the United States Trustee
appoint a committee of equity security holders.&#160;
By letters dated December 26, 2006, the United States Trustee denied
this request.&#160; On January 11, 2007, an ad
hoc committee of equity security holders filed a motion in the Bankruptcy Court
seeking to compel the United States Trustee to appoint an equity
committee.&#160; On February 28, 2007, the
equity holders withdrew their request to appoint an equity committee.&#160; Subsequently, they have sought the
appointment of an examiner to investigate the Company&#146;s plans regarding
industry consolidation.&#160; The Debtors do
not believe this request is appropriate, and will oppose it in the Bankruptcy
Court.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Operations
and Route Network</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest and its Airlink partners operate
substantial domestic and international route networks and directly serve more
than 240 destinations in 26 countries in North America, Asia and Europe.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Domestic System</font></i></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest operates its domestic system through its hubs at Detroit,
Minneapolis/St. Paul and Memphis.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Detroit</font></i>.&#160; Detroit is the ninth largest
origination/destination hub in the U.S.&#160;
Northwest and its Airlink carriers together serve over 150 destinations
from Detroit.&#160; For the six months ended
June 30, 2006, they enplaned 56% of originating passengers from Detroit, while
the next largest competitor enplaned 13%.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Minneapolis/St. Paul.&#160; </font></i>Minneapolis/St. Paul is the eighth largest
origination/destination hub in the U.S.&#160;
Northwest and its Airlink carriers together serve over 160 destinations
from Minneapolis/St. Paul.&#160; For the six
months ended June 30, 2006, they enplaned 61% of originating passengers from
Minneapolis/St. Paul, while the next largest competitor enplaned 13%.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Memphis</font></i>.&#160; Memphis is the seventeenth largest
origination/destination hub in the U.S.&#160;
Northwest and its Airlink carriers together serve 90 destinations from
Memphis.&#160; For the six months ended June
30, 2006, they enplaned 60% of originating passengers from Memphis, while the
next largest competitor enplaned 12%.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Domestic System Operations.</font></i>&#160;
Domestic &#147;non-hub&#148; operations include service to as many as 16
destinations from Indianapolis, service from several heartland cities to New
York, Washington D.C. and Florida destinations, and service from several west
coast gateway cities to Hawaii.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">International System</font></i></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest
operates international flights to the Pacific and/or the Atlantic regions from
its Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul and Memphis hubs, as well as from gateway
cities including Boston, Honolulu, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, and
Portland.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <i>Pacific</i>.&#160; Northwest has served the Pacific market since
1947 and has one of the world&#146;s largest Pacific route networks.&#160; Northwest&#146;s Pacific operations are
concentrated at Narita International Airport in Tokyo, where it has 376
permanent weekly takeoffs and landings (&#147;slots&#148;) as of December 31, 2006, the
most for any non-Japanese carrier.&#160; Under
the U.S. &#151; Japan bilateral aviation agreement, Northwest has the right to
operate unlimited frequencies between any point in the U.S. and Japan as well
as extensive &#147;fifth freedom&#148; rights.&#160;
Fifth freedom rights allow Northwest to operate service from any gateway
in Japan to points beyond Japan and to carry Japanese originating
passengers.&#160; Northwest and United
Airlines, Inc. (&#147;United&#148;) are the only U.S. passenger carriers that have fifth
freedom rights from Japan.&#160; Northwest
uses these slots and rights to operate a network linking seven U.S. gateways
and 12 Asian destinations via Tokyo.&#160; The
Asian destinations served via Tokyo are Bangkok, Beijing, Busan, Guam,
Guangzhou, Hong Kong, Manila, Nagoya, Saipan, Seoul, Shanghai, and
Singapore.&#160; Additionally, Northwest flies
nonstop between Detroit and Osaka and Nagoya, and uses its fifth freedom rights
to fly beyond Osaka to Taipei and beyond Nagoya to Manila.&#160; Northwest also operates nonstop service
between Nagoya and Guam and Saipan and between Osaka and Guam and Honolulu.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; <i>Atlantic</i>.&#160; Northwest and KLM operate an extensive
transatlantic network pursuant to a commercial and operational joint
venture.&#160; This joint venture benefits
from having antitrust immunity, which allows for coordinated pricing,
scheduling, product development and marketing.&#160;
In 1992, the U.S. and the Netherlands entered into an &#147;open-skies&#148;
bilateral aviation treaty, which authorizes the airlines of each country to
provide international air transportation between any U.S. &#151; Netherlands city
pair and to operate connecting service to destinations in other countries.&#160; Northwest and KLM operate joint service
between Amsterdam and 17 cities in the U.S., Canada and Mexico, as well as
between Amsterdam and India.&#160; Codesharing
between Northwest and KLM has been implemented on flights to 59 European, seven
Middle Eastern, 13 African, five Asian and 176 U.S. cities.&#160; Codesharing is an agreement whereby an
airline&#146;s flights can be marketed under the two-letter designator code of
another airline, thereby allowing the two carriers to provide joint service
with one aircraft.&#160; After September 2007,
the Northwest-KLM joint venture can be terminated on three years&#146; notice.&#160; In May 2004, Air France acquired KLM, and KLM
and Air France became wholly-owned subsidiaries of a new holding company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated
Financial Statements and Supplementary Data, Note 19 &#151; Geographic Regions&#148; for
a discussion of Northwest&#146;s operations by geographic region.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Alliances</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; In addition to its transatlantic joint venture with KLM,
Northwest has strengthened its network through other alliance
partnerships.&#160; Long-term alliances are an
effective way for Northwest to enter markets that it would not be able to serve
alone.&#160; Alliance relationships can
include codesharing, reciprocal frequent flyer programs, &#147;through&#148; luggage
check-in, reciprocal airport lounge access,&#160;
joint marketing, sharing of airport facilities and joint procurement of
certain goods and services.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; Since 1998, Northwest and Continental have been in a domestic
and international commercial alliance that connects the two carriers&#146; networks
and includes extensive codesharing, frequent flyer program reciprocity and
other cooperative marketing programs.&#160;
The alliance agreement has a term through December 31, 2025.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In August 2002, the Company entered into a commercial alliance agreement
with Continental and Delta.&#160; This
agreement is designed to connect the three carriers&#146; domestic and international
networks and provides for codesharing, reciprocity of frequent flyer programs,
airport club use and other cooperative marketing programs.&#160; The combined network has increased Northwest&#146;s
presence in the South, East and Mountain West regions of the U.S., as well as
in Latin America.&#160; The alliance agreement
has a term through June 12, 2012, and
if not terminated on that date, continues in effect for five more years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2004, Northwest, together with KLM and Continental
Airlines, joined the global SkyTeam Alliance.&#160;
The addition of Northwest, KLM and Continental made SkyTeam the world&#146;s
second largest airline alliance.&#160; The ten
members of the SkyTeam alliance, Northwest, KLM, Continental, Delta, Air
France, Alitalia, AeroM&#233;xico, CSA Czech Airlines, Korean Air, and Aeroflot
currently serve over 372 million passengers annually with more than 14,600
daily departures to 728 destinations in 149 countries.&#160; Northwest customers are now able to accrue
and redeem frequent flyer miles in their WorldPerks accounts and enjoy travel
on any flight operated by a SkyTeam Alliance member carrier.&#160; This alliance affords customers the benefits
and service options when traveling on multiple airlines while being treated
similarly to a customer traveling on a single airline.&#160; The alliance agreement has a term through June 12, 2012, and if not terminated
on that date, continues in effect for five more years.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">7</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest also has domestic frequent flyer and codesharing agreements
with several other airlines including Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, Hawaiian
Airlines, American Eagle, Gulfstream International Airlines, and Big Sky
Airlines.&#160; In Central America, Northwest
has a frequent flyer agreement with Copa Airlines.&#160; In the Pacific, Northwest has frequent flyer
agreements with Malaysia Airlines, Japan Airlines, Jet Airways of India, Garuda
Indonesia, Cebu Pacific Airlines, Air Tahiti Nui, and China Southern.&#160; In the Atlantic, in addition to its extensive
relationship with KLM, Northwest has frequent flyer agreements with KLM
cityhopper, Air Europa, Kenya Airways and Malev Hungarian Airlines.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:6.0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest and its SkyTeam Alliance and other travel partners currently
provide a global network to over 900 cities in more than 160 countries on six
continents.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Regional Partnerships</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:12.0pt 0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest
has airline services agreements with three regional carriers: Pinnacle Airlines,
Mesaba and Compass.&#160; Pursuant to the
airline service agreements, these regional carriers are required to operate
their flights under the Northwest &#147;NW&#148; code and operate as Northwest
Airlink.&#160; The purpose of these airline
services agreements is to provide service to small cities and more frequent
service to larger cities, increasing connecting traffic at Northwest&#146;s domestic
hubs.&#160; The business terms of these
agreements involve capacity purchase arrangements.&#160; Under these arrangements, Northwest controls
the scheduling, pricing, reservations, ticketing and seat inventories for
Pinnacle Airlines and Mesaba flights.&#160;
Northwest is generally entitled to all ticket, cargo and mail revenues
associated with these flights.&#160; The
regional carriers are paid based on operations for certain expenses and receive
reimbursement for other expenses.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;margin:12.0pt 0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Pinnacle Airlines.</font></i><font size="2" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#160; Pinnacle operated 124 of Northwest&#146;s fleet of
Bombardier Canadair Regional Jet (&#147;CRJ&#148;) CRJ200 aircraft as of December 31,
2006.&#160; The Company owns 11.4% of the
Common Stock of Pinnacle Airlines Corp. and accounts for this investment under
the equity method of accounting.&#160; The
Pinnacle Airlines Corp. Common Stock had a market value of $42.0 million and a
book value of $11.8 million as of December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On December 21, 2006, the Debtors&#146; filed a motion for entry into an
amended airline services agreement (&#147;Amended Pinnacle ASA&#148;) and related
agreements with Pinnacle Airlines.&#160; On
January 11, 2007, the Court entered an order granting the motion.&#160; The Amended Pinnacle ASA provides that
Pinnacle Airlines will continue to be a long-term partner of Northwest through
at least 2017.&#160; In addition to reaching
terms of an amended Pinnacle ASA, Northwest granted Pinnacle Airlines an
allowed general unsecured claim of $377.5 million for full and final
satisfaction of any and all claims filed against the Debtors, which resulted in
an incremental charge to reorganization expense of $306.7 million in January
2007.&#160; The Amended Pinnacle ASA and
related agreements provide Northwest with, among other things, certainty of
Pinnacle Airlines&#146; performance at rates consistent with Northwest&#146;s cost
savings targets and resolution of the Pinnacle Airlines claims.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Mesaba.&#160; </font></i>Mesaba, a wholly-owned subsidiary of MAIR
Holdings, Inc. (&#147;MAIR&#148;), is the operator of 49 SAAB 340 turbo-prop aircraft and
one CRJ200 aircraft.&#160; On October&nbsp;13,
2005, Mesaba filed a voluntary petition for relief under Chapter&nbsp;11 of the
United States Bankruptcy Code in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the
District of Minnesota (Case No. 05-39258 (GFK)).&#160; In accordance with the provisions of the
Bankruptcy Code, Mesaba continues to operate its business as a
debtor-in-possession.&#160; As of December 31,
2006, the Debtors owned 27.5% of MAIR&#146;s Common Stock.&#160; The market value of this investment as of
December 31, 2006 was $40.6 million and the book value was $19.8 million.</p>

<p style="margin:12.0pt 0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On
January 22, 2007, the Debtors entered in to a Stock Purchase and Reorganization
Agreement with Mesaba and a Stock Purchase Agreement with Mesaba&#146;s parent,
MAIR; these agreements were subsequently approved by the Bankruptcy Court.&#160; Pursuant to the agreement, the Debtors&#146;
agreed to purchase all of the equity interests in Mesaba following its
reorganization under Chapter 11 and granted a general unsecured claim of $145
million for full and final satisfaction of any and all claims filed against the
Debtors.&#160; The Debtors&#146; also agreed to
resolve all outstanding claims with MAIR and to sell to MAIR all of Northwest&#146;s
stock in MAIR.&#160; Northwest intends to
enter into a new airline services agreement with Mesaba pursuant to which
Mesaba will continue to provide Northwest Airlink services to Northwest at
rates consistent with Northwest&#146;s cost savings targets. Northwest has entered
into an agreement to acquire Mesaba and has announced its intention, subject to
consummation of the transaction, to have Mesaba operate 36 76-seat CRJ900
aircraft, which are currently on order.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additionally, Mesaba filed its plan of
reorganization (the &#147;Mesaba Plan&#148;) and its disclosure statement with respect to
the Mesaba Plan (the &#147;Mesaba Disclosure Statement&#148;) with the United States
Bankruptcy Court for the District of Minnesota on January 22, 2007 and January
24, 2007, respectively.&#160; On February 28,
2007, the Mesaba Disclosure Statement was approved.&#160; A confirmation hearing is scheduled for April
9, 2007.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial Statements
and Supplementary Data, Note 18 &#151; Related Party Transactions&#148; regarding the
Company&#146;s transactions with Pinnacle Airlines and Mesaba.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Compass</font></i>.&#160;
Compass Airlines, Inc., a wholly-owned indirect subsidiary of NWA Corp.,
was established on March 15, 2006 to operate as a Northwest Airlink
carrier.&#160; When Compass commences flight
operations, which is expected to occur</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">later
in 2007, it will initially operate one 50-seat CRJ200 aircraft.&#160; Thereafter, Northwest expects to place up to
36 76-seat Embraer 175 regional jet aircraft, which are currently on order, at
Compass to be operated by Compass under an airline services agreement with
Northwest.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:12.0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;text-align:left;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Cargo</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is the largest cargo carrier among U.S. passenger airlines
based on revenue, and the only one to operate a dedicated freighter fleet.&#160; In 2006, cargo accounted for 7.5% of the
Company&#146;s operating revenues, with approximately 80% of its cargo revenues
resulting from cargo originating in or destined for Asia.&#160; Through its cargo hubs in Anchorage and
Tokyo, the Company serves most major air freight markets between the U.S. and
Asia with a fleet of dedicated Boeing 747-200 freighter aircraft.&#160; In addition to revenues earned from the
dedicated freighter fleet, the Company also generates cargo revenues in
domestic and international markets through the use of cargo space on its
passenger aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2004, the United States
and the People&#146;s Republic of China agreed to a series of amendments to the 1980
U.S. &#151; China Air Transport Agreement.&#160;
The amendments provide for a significant expansion of air services
between the two countries.&#160; On September
3, 2004, the Department of Transportation (&#147;DOT&#148;) awarded Northwest six
additional U.S. &#151; China all-cargo frequencies, which the Company is using for
freighter service to Shanghai, via its cargo hubs in Anchorage and Tokyo.&#160; Additionally, on February 22, 2005, the DOT
awarded Northwest three additional U.S. &#151; China all-cargo frequencies that
became available on March 25, 2006.&#160; The
Company used these frequencies to start up new freighter all-cargo service to
Guangzhou via the Tokyo hub.&#160; On August
24, 2006, the DOT awarded Northwest four additional US &#151; China all-cargo
frequencies that will become available on March 25, 2007.&#160; The Company intends to use these frequencies
to expand the Guangzhou freighter service.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Effective September 30, 2005, Northwest Airlines Cargo joined SkyTeam
Cargo.&#160; SkyTeam Cargo is the largest
global airline cargo alliance.&#160; The eight
members of SkyTeam Cargo, Northwest Airlines Cargo, AeroM&#233;xico Cargo, Air
France Cargo, Alitalia Cargo, CSA Cargo, Delta Air Logistics, KLM Cargo, and
Korean Air Cargo, currently serve more than 900 cities in more than 229
countries on six continents.&#160; This
alliance offers customers a consistent standard of performance, quality and
detailed attention to service.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Other
Travel Related Activities</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">MLT Inc.&#160; </font></i>MLT Inc. (&#147;MLT&#148;), an indirect wholly-owned
subsidiary of NWA Corp., is among the largest vacation wholesale companies in
the United States.&#160; MLT develops and
markets Worry-Free Vacations that include air transportation, hotel
accommodations and car rentals.&#160; In
addition to its Worry-Free Vacations charter programs, MLT markets and supports
Northwest&#146;s WorldVacations travel packages to destinations throughout the U.S.,
Canada, Mexico, the Caribbean, Europe and Asia, primarily on Northwest.&#160; These vacation programs, in addition to
providing a competitive and quality tour product, increase the sale of
Northwest services and promote and support new and existing Northwest
destinations.&#160; In 2006, MLT had $495
million in operating revenues.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Frequent Flyer Program</font></i>.&#160;
Northwest operates a frequent flyer loyalty program known as &#147;WorldPerks.&#148;&#160; WorldPerks is designed to retain and increase
traveler loyalty by offering incentives for their continued patronage.&#160; Under the WorldPerks program, miles are
earned by flying on Northwest or its alliance partners and by using the services
of program partners for such things as credit card use, hotel stays, car
rentals and other activities.&#160; Northwest
sells mileage credits to the program partners.&#160;
WorldPerks members accumulate mileage in their accounts and later redeem
mileage for free or upgraded travel on Northwest and other participating
airlines.&#160; WorldPerks members that
achieve certain mileage thresholds also receive enhanced service benefits from
Northwest like special service lines, advance flight boarding and upgrades.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">9</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\fc\74145118860_H10056_1873074\5449-1-de.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:51 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Employees</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is labor-intensive and as of December&nbsp;31,
2006, the Company had approximately 30,000 full-time equivalent employees of
whom approximately 1,900 were foreign nationals working primarily in Asia.
Unions represent approximately 85% of the Company&#146;s employees. CBAs provide
standards for wages, hours of work, working conditions, settlement of disputes
and other matters. The major agreements with domestic employees became
amendable or will become amendable on various dates as follows:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">

  <td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:33.54%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Agents and Clerks</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.6%;">

  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.32%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">6,300<br><br></font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.6%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="42%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.66%;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">International
  Association of Machinists &amp; Aerospace<br>
  Workers (&#147;IAM&#148;)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.6%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.36%;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12/31/2011<br><br></font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.34%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="33%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:33.54%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.6%;">

  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.34%;">

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="42%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.66%;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Aircraft Mechanics
  Fraternal Assocation (&#147;AMFA&#148;)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.6%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="9%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.36%;">

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.34%;">
