</table>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:auto;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 54.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(a) </font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>See &#147;Item 1A. Risk Factors - Risk Factors Related to Northwest and the
Airline Industry&#148; for additional information pertaining to the status of
labor discussions with the Flight Attendants.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Regulation</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General.&#160; </font></i>The Airline Deregulation Act of 1978, as
amended, eliminated domestic economic regulation of passenger and freight air
transportation in many regards.&#160;
Nevertheless, the industry remains regulated in a number of areas.&#160; The DOT has jurisdiction over international
route authorities and various consumer protection matters, such as advertising,
denied boarding compensation, baggage liability and access for persons with
disabilities.&#160; Northwest is subject to
regulations of the DOT and the Federal Aviation Administration (&#147;FAA&#148;) because
it holds certificates of public convenience and necessity, air carrier
operating certificates and other authority granted by those agencies.&#160; The FAA regulates flight operations,
including air space control and aircraft standards, maintenance, ground
facilities, transportation of hazardous materials and other technical
matters.&#160; The Department of Justice (&#147;DOJ&#148;)
has jurisdiction over airline competition matters, including mergers and
acquisitions, under federal antitrust laws.&#160;
The Transportation Security Administration (&#147;TSA&#148;) regulates airline and
airport security.&#160; Other federal agencies
have jurisdiction over postal operations, use of radio facilities by aircraft
and certain other aspects of Northwest&#146;s operations.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">International Service</font></i>.&#160;
Northwest operates its international routes under route certificates and
other authorities issued by the DOT. <i>&#160;</i>Many of Northwest&#146;s international
route certificates are permanent and do not require renewal by the DOT.&#160; Certain other international route
certificates and other authorities are temporary and subject to periodic
renewal.&#160; Northwest requests renewals of
these certificates and other authorities when and as appropriate.&#160; The DOT typically renews temporary
authorities on routes when the authorized carrier is providing a reasonable
level of service.&#160; With respect to
foreign air transportation, the DOT must approve agreements between air
carriers, including codesharing agreements, and may grant antitrust immunity
for those agreements in some situations.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest&#146;s right to operate to foreign countries, including Japan,
China and other countries in Asia and Europe, is governed by aviation
agreements between the U.S. and the respective foreign countries.&#160; Many aviation agreements permit an unlimited
number of carriers to operate between the U.S. and a specific foreign country,
while others limit the number of carriers and flights on a given international
route.&#160; From time to time, the U.S. or
its foreign country counterpart may seek to renegotiate or cancel an aviation
agreement.&#160; In the event an aviation
agreement is amended or canceled, such a change could adversely affect
Northwest&#146;s ability to maintain or expand air service to the relevant foreign
country.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">10</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Operations to and from foreign countries are subject to the applicable
laws and regulations of those countries.&#160;
There are restrictions on the number and timing of operations at certain
international airports served by Northwest, including Tokyo.&#160; Additionally, slots for international flights
are subject to certain restrictions on use and transfer.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Aviation Security.&#160; </font></i>The TSA regulates civil aviation security
under the Aviation and Transportation Security Act (&#147;Aviation Security Act&#148;).&#160; This law federalized substantially all
aspects of civil aviation security and requires, among other things, the
implementation of certain security measures by airlines and airports, such as
the requirement that all passenger bags be screened for explosives.&#160; Since the events of September 11, 2001,
Congress has mandated, and the TSA has implemented, numerous security
procedures that have imposed and will continue to impose additional compliance
responsibilities and costs on airlines.&#160;
Funding for airline and airport security under the law is provided in
part by a $2.50 per segment passenger security fee, subject to a limit of $10
per roundtrip.&#160; In addition, the law authorizes
the TSA to impose an air carrier fee, capped by the aggregate of costs paid by
all air carriers in calendar year 2000 for screening passengers and
property.&#160; The per-carrier limit is
capped at the amount expended by that individual air carrier in calendar year
2000.&#160; This cap is to remain in effect
until the TSA revises the per-carrier limit by market share or any other
appropriate method.&#160; In the fiscal year
2005 Department of Homeland Security Appropriations Act, Congress required the
Government Accountability Office (&#147;GAO&#148;) to conduct a review of the carrier
reported costs; as a result of this review, the GAO concluded that the
industry-wide aviation security costs were underreported, leaving an
uncollected air carrier fee.&#160; In January
2006, the Company and a number of U.S. and foreign carriers were notified by
the TSA that a substantial increase in the additional security fee would be
imposed retroactively to the beginning of 2005, and continuing into 2006 and
future years.&#160; The Company, together with
many other affected carriers, is currently disputing this fee assessment.&#160; It is expected that aviation security laws
and processes will continue to be under review and subject to change by the
federal government in the future.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 2004, the TSA implemented a test of a passenger
pre-screening program, named &#147;Secure Flight,&#148; utilizing passenger data provided
to the TSA by U.S. airlines.&#160; On December 17, 2004, the president signed
into law the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004,
which requires the TSA to take additional actions regarding passenger and air
cargo security.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On April 7, 2005, the Bureau of Customs and Border Protection (&#147;CBP&#148;)
issued a rule requiring airlines, for security screening purposes, to
electronically transmit passenger and crew data to the CBP before flights
arrive in or depart from the U.S.&#160; The
CBP also published a final rule in December 2003 requiring airlines to
electronically transmit cargo data before cargo arrives in and departs from the
U.S.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Airport Access.</font></i>&nbsp; Four of the nation&#146;s airports, Chicago
O&#146;Hare, LaGuardia (New York), Kennedy International (New York) and Ronald
Reagan National (Washington, D.C.), were designated by the FAA as &#147;high density
traffic airports.&#148;&nbsp; The number of takeoff and landing slots at these
airports was limited during certain peak demand time periods.&nbsp; Legislation
passed in March 2000 resulted in the elimination of slot restrictions,
effective July 2002 at Chicago O&#146;Hare and January 2007 at LaGuardia and Kennedy
International.&nbsp; In August 2004, the FAA implemented temporary
restrictions&nbsp;at Chicago O&#146;Hare to limit congestion.&nbsp; The Chicago O&#146;Hare
restrictions became a Final&nbsp;Rule effective October 2006 and will continue
through October 2008.&nbsp; The FAA also decided not to eliminate slot
restrictions at LaGuardia&nbsp;as planned due to continued congestion; carriers
are currently operating under&nbsp;a&nbsp;Final Order at LaGuardia, pending a
proposed&nbsp;rulemaking process.&nbsp; The Final Order will remain&nbsp;in
effect until&nbsp;at least November 2008, the earliest that a Final Rule at
LaGuardia could be put in place.&nbsp; The FAA permits the buying, selling,
trading or leasing of slots subject to certain restrictions.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Labor.&#160; </font></i>The Railway Labor Act (&#147;RLA&#148;) governs the
labor relations of employers and employees engaged in the airline
industry.&#160; Comprehensive provisions are
set forth in the RLA establishing the right of airline employees to organize
and bargain collectively along craft or class lines and imposing a duty upon
air carriers and their employees to exert every reasonable effort to make and
maintain collective bargaining agreements.&#160;
The RLA contains detailed procedures that must be exhausted before a
lawful work stoppage may occur.&#160; Pursuant
to the RLA, Northwest has CBAs with six domestic unions representing nine
separate employee groups.&#160; In addition,
Northwest has agreements with four unions representing its employees in
countries throughout Asia.&#160; These
agreements are not subject to the RLA, although Northwest is subject to local
labor laws.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the RLA, an amendable labor contract continues in effect while the
parties negotiate a new contract.&#160; In
addition to direct contract negotiations, the RLA also provides for mediation,
potential arbitration of unresolved issues and a 30-day &#147;cooling-off&#148; period after
the end of which either party can resort to self-help.&#160; The self-help remedies include, but are not
limited to, a strike by the members of the labor union and the imposition of
proposed contract amendments and, in the event of a strike, the hiring of replacement
workers by the Company.&#160;&#160; See &#147;Item 1A.
Risk Factors&#148; for additional labor discussion.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">11</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='11',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Noise Abatement</font></i>.&#160; The Airport Noise and Capacity Act of 1990 (&#147;ANCA&#148;)
recognizes the right of airport operators with special noise problems to
implement local noise abatement procedures as long as such procedures do not
interfere unreasonably with the interstate and foreign commerce of the national
air transportation system.&#160; As a result
of litigation and pressure from airport area residents, airport operators have
taken local actions over the years to reduce aircraft noise.&#160; These actions include restrictions on night
operations, frequency of aircraft operations and various other procedures for
noise abatement.&#160; While Northwest has
sufficient operational and scheduling flexibility to accommodate current local
noise restrictions, its operations could be adversely affected if locally
imposed regulations become more restrictive or widespread.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the direction of the United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization
(the &#147;ICAO&#148;), world governments, including the U.S., continue to consider more
stringent aircraft noise certification standards than that contained in the
ANCA.&#160; A new ICAO noise standard (Chapter
4) was adopted in 2001 that established more stringent noise requirements for
newly manufactured aircraft after January 1, 2006.&#160; As adopted, the new rule is not accompanied
by a mandatory phase-out of in-service Chapter 3 aircraft, including certain
aircraft operated by Northwest.&#160; FAA
reauthorization legislation, known as &#147;Vision 100 &#151; Century of Aviation
Reauthorization Act&#148; and signed into law by the president on December 12, 2003,
required the FAA to issue regulations implementing Chapter 4 noise standards
consistent with ICAO recommendations.&#160; In
July 2005, the FAA issued a rule adopting Chapter 4 standards.&#160; All of the Company&#146;s aircraft will be in
compliance with these new FAA rules either as Stage 3 or Stage 4 aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Safety</font></i>.&#160; The Company is subject to FAA jurisdiction
pertaining to aircraft maintenance and operations, including equipment,
dispatch, communications, training, flight personnel and other matters
affecting air safety.&#160; To ensure
compliance with its regulations, the FAA requires all U.S. airlines to obtain
operating, airworthiness and other certificates, which are subject to
suspension or revocation for cause.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under FAA regulations, the Company has established, and the FAA has
approved, maintenance programs for all aircraft operated by Northwest.&#160; These programs provide for the ongoing
maintenance of Northwest&#146;s aircraft, ranging from frequent routine inspections
to major overhauls.&#160; Northwest&#146;s aircraft
require various levels of maintenance or &#147;checks&#148; and periodically undergo
complete overhauls.&#160; Maintenance programs
are monitored closely by the FAA, with FAA representatives routinely present at
Northwest&#146;s maintenance facilities.&#160; The
FAA issues Airworthiness Directives (&#147;ADs&#148;), which mandate changes to an air
carrier&#146;s maintenance program.&#160; These ADs
(which include requirements for structural modifications to certain aircraft)
are issued to ensure that the nation&#146;s transport aircraft fleet remains
airworthy.&#160; Northwest is currently, and
expects to remain, in compliance with all applicable requirements under all ADs
and the FAA approved maintenance programs.&#160;
The Company is in the process of completing its operating certificate
requirements for Compass with the FAA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A combination of FAA and Occupational Safety and Health Administration
regulations on both the federal and state levels apply to all of Northwest&#146;s
ground-based operations in the United States.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Environmental.&#160; </font></i>The Company is subject to regulation under
various environmental laws and regulations, including the Clean Air Act, the
Clean Water Act and Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and
Liability Act of 1980.&#160; In addition, many
state and local governments have adopted environmental laws and regulations to
which the Company&#146;s operations are subject.&#160;
Environmental laws and regulations are administered by numerous federal
and state agencies.</p>

<p style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In November 2005, the
Environmental Protection Agency (the &#147;EPA&#148;) issued a rule implementing the
aircraft emissions standards previously approved by the ICAO, of which the
United States is a member.&nbsp;Following issuance of the EPA rule,&nbsp;a
lawsuit&nbsp;was filed in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the&nbsp;District of
Columbia Circuit&nbsp;on behalf of state and local air regulators&nbsp;against
the EPA challenging its rule regulating aircraft emissions on the grounds that
the international emissions standards codified by the EPA rule are not
stringent enough.&nbsp; Northwest believes it is in compliance with the
emissions standards that were codified by the EPA rule.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest, along with other airlines, has been identified as a
potentially responsible party at various environmental sites.&#160; Management believes that Northwest&#146;s share of
liability for the cost of the remediation of these sites, if any, will not have
a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Civil Reserve Air Fleet Program.&#160; </font></i>Northwest renewed its participation in the Civil Reserve Air Fleet
Program (&#147;CRAF&#148;), pursuant to which Northwest has agreed to make available,
during the period beginning October 1, 2006 and ending September 30, 2007, 19
Boeing 747-200/400 passenger aircraft, 16 Boeing 757-300 passenger aircraft, 13
Airbus A330-300 passenger aircraft, 11 Airbus A330-200 passenger aircraft and
12 Boeing 747-200 freighter aircraft for use by the U.S. military under certain
stages of readiness related to national emergencies.&#160; The program is a standby arrangement that
allows the U.S. Department of Defense U.S. Air Force Air Mobility Command to
call on some or all of these 71 contractually committed Northwest aircraft and
their crews to supplement military airlift capabilities.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='12',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
1A.&#160; RISK FACTORS</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Risk Factors Related to Northwest and the Airline Industry</font></b></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">The airline industry is intensely
competitive.</font></i></b></h1>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is intensely
competitive.&#160; Our competitors include
other major domestic airlines as well as foreign, regional and new entrant
airlines, some of which have more financial resources and/or lower cost
structures than ours.&#160; In most of our
markets we compete with at least one of these carriers.&#160; Our revenues are sensitive to numerous
factors, and the actions of other carriers in the areas of pricing, scheduling
and promotions can have a substantial adverse impact on our revenues.</font></h1>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Industry revenues are also impacted by growth
of low cost airlines and the use of internet travel Web sites.&#160; Using the advantage of low unit costs, driven
in large part by lower labor costs, low cost carriers and carriers who have
achieved lower labor costs are able to operate profitably while offering
substantially lower fares.&#160; Internet
travel Web sites have driven significant distribution cost savings for
airlines, but have also allowed consumers to become more efficient at finding
lower fare alternatives than in the past by providing them with more powerful
pricing information.&#160; Such factors become
even more significant in periods when the industry experiences large losses, as
airlines under financial stress, or in bankruptcy, may institute pricing
structures intended to protect market share, or raise cash quickly,
irrespective of the impact to long-term profitability.</font></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Global events have also significantly impacted airline industry
revenue.&#160; The war in Iraq depressed air
travel, particularly on international routes.&#160;
The outbreak of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (&#147;SARS&#148;) sensitized
passengers to the potential for air travel to facilitate the spread of
contagious diseases.&#160; An escalation of
the war in Iraq, or another outbreak of SARS, Avian flu, or other
influenza-type illness, if it were to persist for an extended period, could
again materially affect the airline industry and the Company by reducing
revenues and impacting travel behavior.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Approval of the Company&#146;s Plan of
Reorganization is not assured.</font></i></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In order to exit Chapter 11 successfully, the Company must propose, and
obtain confirmation by the Bankruptcy Court of, a plan of reorganization that
satisfies the requirements of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; The Plan must be voted on by holders of
impaired claims, and must satisfy certain requirements of the Bankruptcy Code
and be confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court.&#160;
Although we have filed our Plan for emergence from Chapter 11, there can
be no assurance that the Plan will be approved by claim holders or confirmed by
the Bankruptcy Court.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">A strike or other form of self-help by the
flight attendants could have a material adverse effect on the Company.</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Labor has always been a critical issue for major airlines, including the
Company.&#160;&#160; Approximately 85% of our
employees are represented by unions.&#160;
Salary and benefit costs are our second largest operating expense and
reducing these expenses by approximately $1.4 billion was a major goal of our
restructuring plan.&#160; In connection with
its labor cost restructuring, the Company has been successful in implementing
new labor agreements with the majority of its labor groups including ALPA, the
IAM, ATSA, TWU, NAMA and AMFA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has not reached a ratified consensual agreement with respect
to its flight attendants, represented by the AFA-CWA.&#160; For additional labor discussion, including
background on the Company&#146;s collective bargaining negotiations with its flight
attendants and legal actions taken by the flight attendants, see &#147;Item 7.
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations &#151; Chapter 11 Proceedings.&#148;&#160; In
accordance with the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s previous authorization, the Company
implemented new contract terms and conditions for its flight attendants.&#160; The Company is currently in mediated
negotiations with the AFA-CWA and representatives of the National Mediation
Board (&#147;NMB&#148;).&#160; The AFA-CWA has requested
that it be released from further negotiations by the NMB; to date the NMB has
not granted this request.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the RLA, an amendable labor contract continues in effect while the
parties negotiate a new contract.&#160; In
addition to direct contract negotiations, the RLA also provides for mediation,
potential arbitration of unresolved issues and a 30-day &#147;cooling-off&#148; period
after the end of which either party can resort to self-help.&#160; The self-help remedies include, but are not
limited to, a strike by the members of the labor union and the imposition of
proposed contract amendments and, in the event of a strike, the hiring of
replacement workers by the Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company cannot predict, at this time, the outcome of the AFA-CWA&#146;s
appeal of the U.S. District Court&#146;s ruling regarding the flight attendants&#146;
right to strike or to engage in other job actions, nor can we predict the
outcome of the negotiations with the AFA-CWA or when the AFA-CWA may be
released by the NMB.&#160; A strike or other
form of self-help could have a material adverse effect on the Company.&#160; In addition, if the Company does not achieve
the targeted level of</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">13</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='13',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">savings
under a flight attendant agreement, the amount of labor savings achieved
through its other ratified CBAs would be subject to reduction.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">The Company&#146;s
degree of leverage may limit its financial and operating activities.</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company will have
significant indebtedness even after the Plan is consummated.&#160; Further, our historical capital requirements
have been significant and our future capital requirements are significant;
these requirements may also be affected by general economic conditions,
industry trends, performance, and many other factors that are not within our
control. The Company cannot ensure that we will be able to obtain financing in
the future.&#160; Even if the Plan is approved
and consummated, the Company cannot ensure that we will not experience losses
in the future.&#160; Our profitability and
ability to generate cash flow will likely depend upon our ability to implement
successfully our business strategy.&#160;
However, the Company cannot ensure that we will be able to accomplish
these results.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">The covenants in the Company&#146;s exit facility may restrict the
reorganized Company&#146;s activities and will require satisfaction of certain
financial tests.</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s exit facility
will contain a number of covenants and other provisions that may restrict the
reorganized Company&#146;s ability to engage in various financing transactions and
operating activities. The exit facility also will require the reorganized
Company to satisfy certain financial tests.&#160;
The ability of the reorganized Company to meet these financial covenants
may be affected by events beyond its control.&#160;
If the reorganized Company defaults under any of these requirements, the
lenders could declare all outstanding borrowings, accrued interest and fees to
be due and payable.&#160; If that were to
occur, there can be no assurance that the Company would have sufficient
liquidity to repay or refinance this indebtedness or any of its other debt.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Changes in
government regulations could increase our operating costs and limit our ability
to conduct our business.</font></i></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Airlines
are subject to extensive regulatory requirements in the U.S. and
internationally.&#160; In the last several
years, Congress has passed laws and the FAA has issued a number of maintenance
directives and other operating regulations that impose substantial costs on
airlines.&#160; Additional laws, regulations,
taxes and airport charges have been proposed from time to time that could
significantly increase the cost of airline operations or reduce revenues.&#160; The ability of U.S. carriers to operate
international routes is subject to change because the applicable arrangements
between the U.S. and foreign governments may be amended from time to time, or
because appropriate landing slots or facilities may not be available.&#160; We cannot give assurance that laws or
regulations enacted in the future will not adversely affect the industry or the
Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">We are
vulnerable to increases in aircraft fuel costs.</font></i></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because fuel costs are a significant portion
of our operating costs, substantial changes in fuel costs would materially
affect our operating results.&#160; Fuel
prices continue to be susceptible to, among other factors, political unrest in
various parts of the world, Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (&#147;OPEC&#148;)
policy, the rapid growth of economies in China and India, the levels of
inventory carried by industries, the amounts of reserves built by governments,
disruptions to production and refining facilities and weather.&#160; In 2005 Hurricane Katrina and Hurricane Rita
caused widespread disruption to oil production, refinery operations and
pipeline capacity in portions of the U.S. Gulf Coast.&#160; As a result of these disruptions, the price
of jet fuel increased significantly and the availability of jet fuel supplies
diminished during the fall of 2005.&#160;
These and other factors that impact the global supply and demand for
aircraft fuel may affect our financial performance due to its high sensitivity
to fuel prices.&#160; A one-cent change in the
cost of each gallon of fuel would impact operating expenses by approximately
$1.5 million per month (based on our 2006 mainline and regional aircraft fuel
consumption).&#160; The Company&#146;s mainline
fuel expense per available seat mile increased from 2.99 cents to 3.43 cents,
on average, from 2005 to 2006.&#160; From time
to time, we hedge some of our future fuel purchases to protect against
potential spikes in price.&#160; However,
these hedging strategies may not always be effective and can result in losses
depending on price changes.&#160; As of
January 31, 2007, the Company has hedged the price of approximately 40% of its
estimated 2007 fuel requirements, compared to no fuel hedges being in place at
December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Our insurance
costs have increased substantially and further increases could harm our
business.</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following September 11, 2001, aviation insurers
significantly increased airline insurance premiums and reduced the maximum
amount of coverage available to airlines for certain types of claims.&#160; Our total aviation and other insurance
expenses were $48 million higher in 2006 than in 2000.&#160; The FAA is currently providing aviation war
risk insurance as required by the Homeland Security Act of 2002 as amended by
the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2005 and subsequently by the Continuing
Appropriations Resolution 2007.&#160; However,
following multiple extensions, this coverage is scheduled to expire on August
31, 2007.&#160; While the government may again
extend the period that it provides excess war risk coverage, there is no
assurance that this will occur, or if it does, how long the extension will
last, what will be included in the coverage, or at what cost the coverage will
be provided.&#160; Should the U.S. government
stop providing war risk insurance</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">14</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='14',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">in
its current form to the U.S. airline industry, it is expected that the premiums
charged by commercial aviation insurers for this coverage, if available at all,
would be substantially higher than the premiums currently charged by the
government, the maximum amount of coverage available would be reduced, and the
type of coverage could be more restrictive.&#160;
Commercial aviation insurers could further increase insurance premiums
and reduce or cancel coverage, in the event of a new terrorist attack or other
events adversely affecting the airline industry.&#160; Significant increases in insurance premiums
could negatively impact our financial condition and results of operations.&#160; If we are unable to obtain adequate war risk
insurance, our business could be materially and adversely affected.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If we were to be involved in an accident, we could be
exposed to significant tort liability.&#160;
Although we carry insurance to cover damages arising from such
accidents, resulting tort liability could be higher than our policy limits
which could negatively impact our financial condition.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">We are exposed to foreign currency exchange
rate fluctuations.</font></i></b></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We conduct a significant portion of our
operations in foreign locations.&#160; As a
result, we have operating revenues and, to a lesser extent, operating expenses,
as well as assets and liabilities, denominated in foreign currencies,
principally the Japanese yen.&#160;
Fluctuations in foreign currencies can significantly affect our
operating performance and the value of our assets and liabilities located
outside of the United States.&#160; From time
to time, we use financial instruments to hedge our exposure to the Japanese
yen.&#160; However, these hedging strategies
may not always be effective.&#160; As of
December 31, 2006, the Company has no forward contracts outstanding related to
its anticipated 2007 yen-denominated sales.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">We are exposed to changes in interest rates.</font></i></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">We had $6.9 billion of debt and capital lease obligations that were
accruing interest as of December 31, 2006 and $2.5 billion of total balance sheet
cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments as of December 31,
2006.&#160; Of the indebtedness, 67% bears
interest at floating rates.&#160; An increase
in interest rates would have an overall negative impact on our earnings as
increased interest expense would only be partially offset by increased interest
income.&#160; From time to time, we use
financial instruments to hedge our exposure to interest rate fluctuations.&#160; However, these hedging strategies may not
always be effective.&#160; As of December 31,
2006 the Company had entered into individual interest rate cap hedges related
to three floating rate debt instruments, with a total cumulative notional
amount of $504 million.&#160; The objective of
the interest rate cap hedges is to protect the anticipated payments of interest
(cash flows) on the designated debt instruments from adverse market interest
rate changes.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Any &#147;ownership change&#148; could limit
our ability to utilize our net operating loss carryforwards.</font></i></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &#147;Internal
Revenue Code&#148;), a corporation is generally allowed a deduction in any taxable
year for net operating losses carried over from prior years.&#160; As of December 31, 2006, the Company had
approximately $3.3 billion of federal and state net operating loss (&#147;NOL&#148;)
carryforwards.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A corporation&#146;s use of its NOL carryforwards is generally limited under
Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code if a corporation undergoes an &#147;ownership
change.&#148;&#160; However, when an &#147;ownership
change&#148; occurs pursuant to the implementation of a plan of reorganization under
the Bankruptcy Code (as will be the case on the effective date of the Company&#146;s
Plan), special rules in either Section 382(l)(5) or Section 382(l)(6) of the
Internal Revenue Code apply instead of the general Section 382 limitation
rules.&#160; In general terms, Sections
382(l)(5) or (l)(6) allow for a more favorable utilization of a company&#146;s NOL
carryforwards than would otherwise have been available following an &#147;ownership
change&#148; not in connection with a plan of reorganization.&#160; We have not yet determined whether we will be
eligible for, or will rely on, Section 382(l)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code,
or whether we will instead rely on Section 382(l)(6) of the Internal Revenue
Code.&#160; Assuming we rely on Section
382(l)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code, a second &#147;ownership change&#148; within two
years from the effective date of the Plan would eliminate completely our
ability to utilize our NOL carryforwards.&#160;
Even if we rely on Section 382(l)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code, an &#147;ownership
change&#148; after the effective date of the Plan could significantly limit our
ability to utilize our NOL carryforwards for taxable years including or
following the subsequent &#147;ownership change.&#148;&#160;
To avoid a potential adverse effect on our ability to utilize our NOL
carryforwards after the effective date of the Plan, we have proposed
restrictions on certain transfers of Common Stock of the reorganized NWA Corp.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-indent:18.0pt;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Due to industry seasonality,
operating results for any interim periods are not necessarily indicative of
those for the entire year.</font></i></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is seasonal in nature.&#160; Due to seasonal fluctuations, operating
results for any interim period are not necessarily indicative of those for the
entire year.&#160; Our second and third
quarter operating results have historically been more favorable due to
increased leisure travel on domestic and international routes during the summer
months.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">15</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='15',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Forward-Looking Statements</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Certain of the statements made in &#147;Item 1.&#160; Business,&#148; &#147;Item 7. Management&#146;s Discussion
and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; and elsewhere in
this annual report are forward-looking and are based upon information available
to the Company on the date hereof.&#160; The
Company, through its management, may also from time to time make oral
forward-looking statements.&#160; In
connection with the &#147;safe harbor&#148; provisions of the Private Securities
Litigation Reform Act of 1995, the Company is hereby identifying important
factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those
contained in any forward-looking statement made by or on behalf of the
Company.&#160; Any such statement is qualified
by reference to the following cautionary statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company believes that the material risks and uncertainties that
could affect the outlook of an airline operating under Chapter 11 and in a
global economy include, among others, the ability of the Company to continue as
a going concern, the ability of the Company to obtain and maintain any
necessary financing for operations and other purposes, the ability of the
Company to maintain adequate liquidity, the ability of the Company to absorb
escalating fuel costs, the Company&#146;s ability to obtain court approval with
respect to motions in the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings prosecuted by it from time
to time, the ability of the Company to develop, confirm and consummate a plan
of reorganization with respect to its Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings, risks
associated with third parties seeking and obtaining court approval to terminate
or shorten the exclusivity period for the Company to propose and confirm a plan
of reorganization, to appoint a Chapter&nbsp;11 trustee or to convert the cases
to Chapter 7 cases, the ability of the Company to obtain and maintain normal
terms with vendors and service providers, the Company&#146;s ability to maintain
contracts that are critical to its operations, the ability of the Company to
realize assets and satisfy liabilities without substantial adjustments and/or
changes in ownership, the potential adverse impact of the Chapter&nbsp;11 proceedings
on the Company&#146;s liquidity or results of operations, the ability of the Company
to operate pursuant to the terms of its financing facilities (particularly the
related financial covenants), the ability of the Company to attract, motivate
and/or retain key executives and associates, the future level of air travel
demand, the Company&#146;s future passenger traffic and yields, the airline industry
pricing environment, increased costs for security, the cost and availability of
aviation insurance coverage and war risk coverage, the general economic
condition of the United States and other regions of the world, the price and
availability of jet fuel, the war in Iraq, the possibility of additional
terrorist attacks or the fear of such attacks, concerns about SARS, Avian flu
or other influenza or contagious illnesses, labor strikes, work disruptions,
labor negotiations both at other carriers and the Company, low cost carrier
expansion, capacity decisions of other carriers, actions of the U.S. and
foreign governments, foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations, inflation and
other factors discussed herein.&#160;
Additional information with respect to these factors and these and other
events that could cause differences between forward-looking statements and
future actual results is contained in &#147;Risk Factors Related to Northwest and
the Airline Industry&#148; above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Developments in any of these areas, as well as other risks and
uncertainties detailed from time to time in the Company&#146;s Securities and
Exchange Commission filings, could cause the Company&#146;s results to differ from
results that have been or may be projected by or on behalf of the Company.&#160; The Company undertakes no obligation to
publicly update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result
of new information, future events or otherwise.&#160;
These statements deal with the Company&#146;s expectations about the future
and are subject to a number of factors that could cause actual results to
differ materially from the Company&#146;s expectations.&#160; All subsequent written or oral
forward-looking statements attributable to the Company, or persons acting on
behalf of the Company, are expressly qualified in their entirety by the factors
described above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
1B.&#160; UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None</font>.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item
2.&#160; PROPERTIES</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Flight Equipment</font></b></p>

aircraft at December 31, 2006, consisting of 312 narrow-body and 59 wide-body
aircraft.&#160; Northwest&#146;s purchase
commitments for aircraft as of December 31, 2006 are also provided.</font></p>

  <td width="31%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:31.04%;">

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:7.12%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">105</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)&#160;&#160; On January 8, 2007, the last
DC10-30 aircraft retired from scheduled service.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)&#160;&#160; The Company intends to remove
two Boeing 747F aircraft from scheduled service in early 2007.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(3)&#160;&#160; Excluding DC9 and DC10-30 aircraft, the
average age of Northwest-operated aircraft is 10.3 years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In total, the Company took delivery of two Airbus A330-300 and four
A330-200 aircraft during the twelve months ended December 31, 2006.&#160; The Company entered into debt agreements on
the six aircraft with an aggregate amount of debt incurred of $444 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the quarter ended December 31, 2006, the Company reached agreements with the applicable lenders to restructure
the existing 126 CRJ200 aircraft fleet.&#160;
This agreement included the return of 15 previously rejected CRJ200
aircraft into the Northwest Airlink fleet bringing the Airlink CRJ200 fleet
total to 141 aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">See &#147;Item 8. Consolidated Financial Statements and Supplementary Data,
Note 13 &#151; Commitments&#148; for further information related to the Company&#146;s
aircraft and commitments.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">17</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='17',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Airport Facilities</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest leases the majority of its airport facilities.&#160; The associated lease terms cover periods up
to 30 years and contain provisions for periodic adjustment of lease
payments.&#160; At most airports that it serves,
Northwest has entered into agreements that provide for the non-exclusive use of
runways, taxiways, terminals and other facilities.&#160; Landing fees under these agreements normally
are based on the number of landings and weight of the aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In certain cases, the Company has constructed facilities on leased land
that revert to the lessor upon expiration of the lease.&#160; These facilities include cargo buildings in
Boston, Los Angeles, Seattle and Honolulu; support buildings at the
Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport; a line maintenance hangar in
Seattle; and several hangars in Detroit.&#160;
In addition, we have a maintenance base under operating lease located in
Minneapolis/St. Paul.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company was responsible for managing and supervising the design and
construction of the $1.4 billion McNamara terminal at Detroit Metropolitan
Wayne County Airport.&#160; Phase One was
completed in February 2002 and included 97 gates, 106 ticket-counter positions,
22 security check points, nearly 85 shops and restaurants, four WorldClubs, an
11,500-space parking facility, covered curbside drop-off areas, 18 luggage
carousels and a 404-room hotel.&#160; Phase
Two was completed in July 2006 which provided 25 additional gates and an
expanded west concourse WorldClub.&#160; The
Company is also managing and supervising the design and construction of a $60
million luggage system security expansion project, scheduled to be
operationally complete in late 2008.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport has substantially completed a
$2.9 billion construction program that began in 1998.&#160; The major components completed include a new
north/south runway, an additional 15 mainline jet gates, 30 commuter gates, a
50% increase in vehicle parking and new automated people movers.&#160; Northwest currently has 66 mainline and 35
commuter gates at the airport.&#160; The
airport is also considering a three-phase $860 million plan to expand terminal
facilities to meet air service demand through the year 2020.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Other Property and Equipment</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Northwest&#146;s primary offices are located near the Minneapolis/St. Paul
International Airport, including its corporate offices located on a 160-acre
site east of the airport.&#160; Owned
facilities include reservations centers in Baltimore, Tampa and Chisholm,
Minnesota, and a data processing center in Eagan, Minnesota.&#160; The Company also owns property in Tokyo,
including a 1.3-acre site in downtown Tokyo and a 33-acre land parcel, 512-room
hotel and flight kitchen located near Tokyo&#146;s Narita International
Airport.&#160; In addition, the Company leases reservations centers in or
near Minneapolis/St. Paul and Seattle.</font></p>

<h6 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 3.&#160; LEGAL
PROCEEDINGS</font></b></h6>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On September 14, 2005, NWA Corp. and certain
of its direct and indirect subsidiaries filed voluntary petitions for relief
under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code with the United States
Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York.&#160; Subsequently, on September 30, 2005, NWA
Aircraft Finance, Inc., an indirect subsidiary of NWA Corp., also filed a voluntary
petition for relief under Chapter 11.&#160; </font>The Bankruptcy Court is jointly administering
these cases under the caption &#147;In re Northwest Airlines Corporation, et al.,
Case No. 05-17930 (ALG)&#148;.&#160; Each of the Debtors continues to operate its
business and manage its property as a debtor-in-possession pursuant to Sections
1107 and 1108 of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; As
a result of the current Chapter 11 filings, attempts to collect, secure or
enforce remedies with respect to pre-petition claims against the Debtors are
subject to the automatic stay provisions of Section 362(a) of the Bankruptcy
Code, including the litigation described below.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Chase v. Northwest Airlines and Airline Reporting Corporation </font></i>(U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ.
Action No. 96-74711).&#160; In October 1996,
an antitrust class action, <i>Chase v. Northwest
Airlines and Airline Reporting Corporation</i> (the &#147;Chase Action&#148;) was
filed against Northwest, among other airlines, in the United States District
Court for the Eastern District of Michigan<i>.</i>&#160; The action purported to be brought on behalf
of a class defined as all persons who purchased tickets on certain routes into
Northwest&#146;s hubs at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul and Memphis from October 11,
1992 to the present.&#160; The complaint
alleged that Northwest&#146;s imposition of restrictions prohibiting the sale of &#147;hidden
city&#148; tickets constitutes monopolization in violation of the Sherman Act.&#160; The complaint sought injunctive relief,
unspecified damages for the class, and costs and attorneys&#146; fees.&#160; The attorneys for the plaintiff in the Chase Action filed three additional class
actions in the same court against other airlines and Northwest with parallel
allegations similar to those in Chase, including allegations that the defendant
airlines conspired to deter hidden city ticketing.&#160; These cases are: <i>Keystone
Business Machines, Inc. v. U.S. Airways and Northwest Airlines </i>(U.S.
D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action No. 99-72474)<i>, BLT Contracting, Inc. v. U.S. Airways, Northwest Airlines and the
Airline Reporting Corporation </i>(U.S. D.C. Eastern District of
Michigan, Civ. Action No. 99-72988)<i>, </i>and <i>Volk and Nitrogenous Industries Corp. v. U.S. Airways, Northwest
Airlines, Delta Air Lines, and the Airline Reporting Corporation </i>(U.S.
D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ. Action No. 99-72987)<i>.</i>&#160; All three actions
were assigned to the judge in the Chase Action.&#160;
On August 21, 2006, the plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the litigation
against Northwest and the other defendants and on August 25, 2006, the
plaintiffs withdrew their proof of claim.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Spirit Airlines v. Northwest Airlines </font></i>(U.S. D.C. Eastern District of Michigan, Civ.
Action No. 00-71535).&#160; In March 2000,
Spirit Airlines filed a Sherman Act monopolization complaint against Northwest
in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan alleging that
Northwest had monopolized, or attempted to monopolize, air transportation
service between Detroit and Philadelphia and between Detroit and Boston in 1996
by engaging in predatory pricing and other actions to exclude Spirit from those
markets.&#160; Northwest believes the case to
be without merit and intends to defend against the claim.&#160; On March 31, 2003, the Court granted
Northwest&#146;s motion for summary judgment.&#160;
In October 2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved a stipulation to lift the
stay for the limited purpose of permitting the Sixth Circuit to issue its
opinion.&#160; On November 9, 2005, the Sixth
Circuit issued a decision in which it reversed the trial court&#146;s grant of
summary judgment in favor of Northwest.&#160;
Northwest has filed a petition for <i>en
banc</i> reconsideration before the Sixth Circuit.&#160; On April 13, 2006, the Sixth Circuit denied
Northwest&#146;s request for <i>en banc</i>
review.&#160; On October 2, 2006 the Supreme
Court denied Northwest&#146;s petition for certiorari. </p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Series C Preferred Stock
Litigation.</font></i>&#160; In June 2003, the IBT and certain related
parties commenced litigation against Northwest Airlines Corporation in New York
state court, <i>International Brotherhood of Teamsters,
Local 2000 et al. v. Northwest Airlines Corporation </i>(New York Sup.
Ct., Case No. 601742/03).&#160; In August
2003, the IAM and a related party also commenced litigation against Northwest
Airlines Corporation in New York state court, <i>International
Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers et al. v. Northwest Airlines
Corporation </i>(New York Sup. Ct., Case No. 602476/03)&#160; (together with the IBT&#146;s action, the &#147;Series
C Preferred Stock Actions&#148;). Both lawsuits challenged the Company&#146;s decision
not to purchase its Series C Preferred Stock and sought to compel the Company
to repurchase the Series C Preferred Stock that had been put to the
Company.&#160; The Company announced on August
1, 2003, that the Board of Directors had determined that the Company could not
legally repurchase the outstanding Series C Preferred Stock at that time
because the Board was unable to determine that the Company had adequate surplus
to repurchase the outstanding Series C Preferred Stock.&#160; Before discovery was complete, plaintiffs
filed motions for summary judgment.&#160; On
March 24, 2005, the court ruled that the Company had breached the arrangements
related to the Series C Preferred Stock, and indicated that a trial on damages
would be necessary.&#160; On August 24, 2005,
Northwest and the plaintiffs reached an agreement, among other things, to
cancel the trial and to establish the amount of damages owed to employees
represented by the plaintiffs should the trial court&#146;s liability determination
be upheld (nearly $277 million).&#160; The
agreement also established the procedural process for Northwest to appeal the
trial court&#146;s liability judgment and to seek a stay of enforcement of the
judgment.&#160; The plaintiffs also agreed not
to take any action to enforce the judgment unless and until the New York State
Appellate Division denies Northwest&#146;s motion to stay enforcement of the
judgment.&#160; The Plan as filed provides
that the trial court&#146;s liability judgment in respect of this litigation will be
treated as an allowed unsecured claim.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">In re Northwest Airlines Privacy Litigation</font></i>&#160;
(U.S.D.C. District of Minnesota, Civ. File No. 04-126).&#160; In 2004, several purported class actions were
filed, and subsequently consolidated, in federal court in Minnesota alleging
violations by Northwest of the Electronic Communications Privacy Act, the Fair
Credit Reporting Act and various state laws in connection with the release by
Northwest of certain passenger records to the National Aeronautics and Space
Administration in late 2001.&#160; Similar
purported class actions were filed in federal court in North Dakota, <i>Dyer v. Northwest Airlines Corp.</i> (U.S.D.C.
District of North Dakota, Case No. A1-04-033), and in federal court in
Tennessee, <i>Copeland v. Northwest Airlines
Corp.</i> (U.S.D.C. Western District of Tennessee, Civil File No.
04-CV-2156).&#160; On June 6, 2004, the
District Court in the Minnesota action granted Northwest&#146;s motion for summary
judgment on all claims and that decision is on appeal before the U.S. Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit.&#160; On
September 8, 2004, the District Court in the North Dakota action granted
Northwest&#146;s motion for summary judgment on all claims and the plaintiffs did
not seek appellate review.&#160; On February
28, 2005, the Tennessee District Court dismissed the Tennessee case and
plaintiffs did not appeal.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, in the ordinary course of its business, the Company is
party to various other legal actions which the Company believes are incidental
to the operation of its business.&#160; The
Company believes that the outcome of the proceedings to which it is currently a
party (including those described above) will not have a material adverse effect
on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements taken as a whole.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\Fc\74121216996_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:12 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<h6 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><font style="font-weight:bold;">Item 4.&#160; SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY
HOLDERS</font><a name="Item4_SubmissionOfMattersToAVoteO_002652"></a></font></b></h6>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">No
matters were submitted to a vote of the Company&#146;s security holders during the
fourth quarter of 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">MANAGEMENT</font></b></p>

<h2 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold;">Executive Officers of the Registrant</font></i></b></h2>

<h2 style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:22.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Douglas M. Steenland</font></b>,
age 55, has served as President and Chief Executive Officer of NWA Corp. and
Northwest since October 2004 and was elected a director of both companies in
September 2001. He has served in a number of executive positions since joining
Northwest in 1991, including President from April 2001 to October 2004,
Executive Vice President and Chief Corporate Officer from September 1999 to
April 2001, Executive Vice President-Alliances, General Counsel and Secretary
from January 1999 to September 1999, Executive Vice President, General Counsel
and Secretary from June 1998 to January 1999, and Senior Vice President,
General Counsel and Secretary from July 1994 to June 1998. Prior to joining
Northwest, Mr. Steenland was a senior partner at the Washington, D.C. law firm
of&#160; Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson
and Hand.</h2>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:22.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Neal S.
Cohen</font></b>, age 46, has
served as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of the Company
since May 2005.&#160; Prior to rejoining the
Company, Mr. Cohen served at US Airways as Executive Vice President and Chief
Financial Officer from April 2002 to April 2004, and served as Chief Financial
Officer for Conseco Finance from April 2001 to March 2002.&#160; Prior to his position at Conseco Finance, Mr.
Cohen served as Chief Financial Officer for Sylvan Learning Systems.&#160; From 1991 to 2000, Mr. Cohen held a number of
senior marketing and finance positions at Northwest Airlines, including Senior
Vice President and Treasurer and Vice President Market Planning.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:22.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">J.
Timothy Griffin</font></b>, age
55, has served as Executive Vice President-Marketing and Distribution of
Northwest since January 1999.&#160; From June
1993 to January 1999, he served as Senior Vice President-Market Planning and
Systems.&#160; Prior to joining Northwest in
1993, Mr. Griffin held senior positions with Continental Airlines and American
Airlines.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:22.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Philip
C. Haan</font></b>, age 51, has
served as Executive Vice President-International, Alliances and Information
Technology of Northwest since October 2004.&#160;
From January 1999 to October 2004, he served as Executive Vice
President-International, Sales and Information Services.&#160; Mr. Haan formerly held positions of Senior
Vice President-International Services, Vice President-Pricing and Area
Marketing, Vice President-Inventory Sales and Systems and Vice President-Revenue
Management.&#160; Prior to joining Northwest
in 1991 he was with American Airlines for nine years.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:22.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Andrew C. Roberts</font></b>, age 46, has served as Executive Vice President &#151; Operations since
November 2004.&#160; He has served in a number
of executive positions since joining Northwest in 1997, including Senior Vice
President &#151; Technical Operations from August 2001 to November 2004, Vice
President &#151; Materials Management from April 1999 to August 2001, and Managing
Director &#151; Minneapolis/St. Paul Engine Operations from September 1997 to April
1999.&#160; Prior to joining Northwest, Mr.
Roberts held senior positions with Pratt &amp; Whitney and Aviall, Inc.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\Fc\75211059288_P66472CHE_1879026\5449-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 16 21:11 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;font-weight:bold;">PART II</font></b><a name="PartIi_002711"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;font-weight:bold;">Item 5. &#160;&#160; MARKET FOR REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY,
RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES</font></b><a name="Item5_MarketForRegistrantsCommonE_002713"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;">The
Company&#146;s Common Stock ceased trading on the NASDAQ stock market on September
26, 2005 and now trades in the &#147;over-the-counter&#148; market under the symbol
NWACQ.PK.&#160; However, under the Company&#146;s
Plan, no value is ascribed to the Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock, Preferred
Stock or other equity securities.&#160; Upon
the effective date of the Plan, the outstanding Common and Preferred Stock of
the Company will be cancelled for no consideration and therefore the Company&#146;s
stockholders will no longer have any interest as stockholders in the Company by
virtue of their ownership of the Company&#146;s Common or Preferred Stock prior to
emergence from bankruptcy.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.5pt;">The table below shows the high and low sales prices for
the Company&#146;s Common Stock during 2006 and 2005:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="79" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:59.4pt;">
  <p style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlHTMLTableCenter --></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:36.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="112" colspan="3" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:83.8pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">2006</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:36.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="118" colspan="3" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:88.8pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">2005</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="79" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:59.4pt;">
  <p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Quarter</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:36.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:23.9pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">High</font></b></p>
  </td>

  </td>
  <td width="32" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:23.9pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Low</font></b></p>

</div>

<p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">As of January 31,
2007, there were 3,276 stockholders of record.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">The following table provides information regarding our
equity compensation plans as of December 31, 2006. In November 2005 NWA Corp.
cancelled all unvested restricted stock and some phantom stock awards
outstanding under NWA Corp.&#146;s stock plans. In addition, it is expected that all
stock options and remaining awards under such plans will be cancelled upon NWA
Corp.&#146;s emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Equity
Compensation Plan Information</font></b></p>
