<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;text-autospace:none;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
accompanying notes are an integral part of these consolidated financial
statements.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">47</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='47',FILE='C:\Fc\74121326433_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-fc.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:13 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">NOTES TO
CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</font></b><a name="NotesToConsolidatedFinancialState_204034"></a></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 1&#151;Voluntary Reorganization Under Chapter 11 Proceedings</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Bankruptcy
Proceedings</font></i>. On
September 14, 2005 (the &#147;Petition Date&#148;), NWA Corp. and 12 of its direct and
indirect subsidiaries (collectively, the &#147;Debtors&#148;) filed voluntary petitions
for relief under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code with the
United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Court&#148;).&#160; Subsequently, on September 30,
2005, NWA Aircraft Finance, Inc., an indirect subsidiary of NWA Corp., also
filed a voluntary petition for relief under Chapter 11.&#160; The Bankruptcy Court is jointly administering
these cases under the caption &#147;In re Northwest Airlines Corporation, et al.,
Case No. 05-17930 (ALG)&#148; (the &#147;Chapter 11 case&#148;).&#160; The consolidated financial statements shown
herein include certain subsidiaries that did not file to reorganize under
Chapter 11.&#160; The assets and liabilities
of these subsidiaries are not considered material to the consolidated financial
statements.</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Plan of Reorganization. </font></i>&#160;On January 12, 2007, NWA Corp. and thirteen of
its direct and indirect subsidiaries, including Northwest, filed with the
Bankruptcy Court the Debtors&#146; Joint and Consolidated Plan of Reorganization
Under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160;
On January 12, 2007, the Bankruptcy Court granted the Company an
extension until February 15, 2007 to file the related Disclosure Statement with
respect to Debtors&#146; Joint and Consolidated Plan of Reorganization under Chapter
11 of the Bankruptcy Code (&#147;Disclosure Statement&#148;).&nbsp; Subsequently, on
February 15, 2007, the Company filed its Disclosure Statement and the First
Amended Joint and Consolidated Plan of Reorganization under Chapter 11 of the
Bankruptcy Code (the &#147;Plan&#148; or &#147;Plan of Reorganization&#148;).</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On March 2, 2007, the Company filed a motion
with the Bankruptcy Court, requesting that its exclusivity period for filing a
reorganization plan be extended to June 29, 2007.&#160; During the exclusivity period, which is currently
set to expire March 16, 2007, only the Company can propose a reorganization
plan.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Plan provides for the treatment of claims
of creditors, the implementation of agreements with key labor groups, lenders,
and suppliers, as well as the raising of new equity capital by NWA Corp.&#160; The Plan proposes to restructure the Company&#146;s
balance sheet through the elimination of all pre-petition unsecured debt.&nbsp;
In exchange for their allowed claims, unsecured creditors will receive Common
Stock of the reorganized NWA Corp. and the right to purchase additional Common
Stock in a rights offering. Because all unsecured creditor claims will not be
satisfied in full, the pre-petition equity holders&#146; interests in NWA Corp.&#146;s
Common and Preferred Stock will be cancelled, and those holders will not
receive a distribution.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A hearing on the adequacy of information in
the Disclosure Statement is scheduled for March 26, 2007.&#160; After approval by the Bankruptcy Court, the
Company will distribute the Plan and Disclosure Statement to its creditors and
begin a period of solicitation of creditors for acceptance of the Plan.&#160; The Disclosure Statement contains detailed
information about the Plan, the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s order approving the
Disclosure Statement, notice of the time for filing acceptance or rejection of
the Plan and timing of the hearing to consider confirmation of the Plan, the
rights offering, financial projections and financial estimates regarding the
Debtors&#146; reorganized business enterprise value. The information contained in
the Disclosure Statement is subject to change, whether as a result of
amendments to the Plan, actions of third parties or otherwise.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Nothing contained in this Form 10-K is
intended to be, nor should it be construed as, a solicitation for a vote on the
Plan. The Plan will become effective only if it receives the requisite approval
and is confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court, which the Company currently expects
to occur during the second quarter of 2007.&#160;
However, there can be no assurance that the Bankruptcy Court will confirm
the Plan or that the Plan will be implemented successfully.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Restructuring Goals.&#160; </font></i>The Company identified three major elements essential to transforming
its business and has substantially completed the actions necessary to achieve
its targeted business improvements.&#160; The
three major elements included:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Achieving approximately $2.4 billion in annual cost reductions,
including both labor and non-labor costs;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Resizing and optimization of the Company&#146;s fleet to better serve
Northwest&#146;s markets;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 45.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Restructuring and recapitalization of the Company&#146;s balance sheet,
including a targeted reduction in debt and lease obligations of approximately
$4.2 billion, providing debt and equity levels consistent with long-term
profitability.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company used the provisions of Chapter 11
and other changes implemented in its business to achieve its targeted
restructuring improvements.&#160; Outlined
below is an overview of significant transactions related to labor and non-labor
cost restructuring, fleet optimization, and the Company&#146;s balance sheet
restructuring efforts.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Labor Cost Restructuring.&#160; </font></i>The Company has ratified
collective bargaining agreements (&#147;CBAs&#148;) or implemented contractual terms and
conditions which collectively provide for approximately $1.4 billion in annual labor
cost savings.&#160; The Company has reached consensual agreement on
CBAs with the Air Line Pilots Association (&#147;ALPA&#148;), the International</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">48</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='48',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (&#147;IAM&#148;),
the Aircraft Technical Support Association (&#147;ATSA&#148;), the Transport Workers
Union of America (&#147;TWU&#148;), and the Northwest Airlines Meteorologists Association
(&#147;NAMA&#148;).&#160; The agreements with ALPA, the
IAM, ATSA, TWU, and NAMA were implemented on or before August 1, 2006.&#160; Two rounds of salaried and management
employee pay and benefit cuts have also been achieved and implemented.&#160;&#160; In addition, the Company imposed contract
terms on its technicians represented by the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal
Association (&#147;AMFA&#148;) in August 2005 and, under Section 1113(c) of the Bankruptcy
Code, imposed contract terms on its flight attendants represented by the
Association of Flight Attendants-Communication Workers of America (&#147;AFA-CWA&#148;)
on July 31, 2006.&#160; On November 6, 2006,
the Company reached a ratified agreement with AMFA to end the labor dispute
with the airline&#146;s technicians.&#160; The
agreement maintains the necessary annual labor cost savings from
AMFA-represented employees.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Section 1113(c) of the Bankruptcy Code permits a debtor to move to
reject its CBAs if the debtor first satisfies a number of statutorily
prescribed substantive and procedural prerequisites and obtains the Bankruptcy
Court&#146;s approval of the rejection or the expiration of the statutorily
prescribed time period.&#160; After bargaining
in good faith and sharing relevant information with its unions, a debtor must
make proposals to modify its existing CBAs based on the most complete and
reliable information available at the time.&#160;
The proposed modifications must be necessary to permit the
reorganization of a debtor and must provide that all the affected parties are
treated fairly and equitably.&#160;
Ultimately, rejection of the CBAs is appropriate if </font>the unions refuse to agree to a debtor&#146;s
necessary proposal &#147;without good cause&#148; and the Bankruptcy Court determines
that the balance of the equities favors rejection.&#160;&#160; In October 2005, the Company commenced
Section 1113(c) proceedings with ALPA, the IAM and the Professional Flight
Attendants Association (&#147;PFAA&#148;) and has subsequently reached consensual
agreement with ALPA and the IAM.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With respect to the Company&#146;s flight attendants, the
Company reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with its flight
attendants represented by the PFAA on March 1, 2006 (the &#147;March TA&#148;).&#160; On June 6, 2006, the PFAA announced that the
flight attendants failed to ratify the tentative agreement.&#160; As a result of the flight attendants&#146; failure
to ratify this agreement, the Company requested a ruling from the Bankruptcy
Court on its Section 1113(c) motion to reject its existing flight attendant
labor agreement and to permit the Company to impose new contract terms.&#160; On June 29, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court
granted the Company&#146;s Section 1113(c) motion to reject its contract with the
flight attendants and authorized the Company to implement the terms of the March
TA; however, the Bankruptcy Court stayed implementation of the order until July
17, 2006.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following</font> the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s June
29, 2006 ruling, the Company and the PFAA commenced negotiations to reach a new
agreement.&#160; On July 6, 2006, the Company&#146;s
flight attendants voted to change their union representation from the PFAA to
the AFA-CWA.&#160; Subsequently, the Company
and the AFA-CWA continued negotiations to reach a new agreement, and on July
17, 2006, the parties announced that they reached a new tentative agreement
(the &#147;July TA&#148;).&#160; On July 31, 2006, the
AFA-CWA announced that its members failed to approve the July TA.&#160; As a result of the flight attendants&#146; failure
to ratify the July TA, and in accordance with the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s previous
authorization, effective July 31, 2006 the Company implemented new contract
terms and conditions for its flight attendants, consistent with the terms and
conditions of the March TA.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On
July 31, 2006, following the flight attendants&#146; failure to ratify a second
proposed CBA and the Company&#146;s subsequent imposition of new contract terms for
the flight attendants, the AFA-CWA provided the Company with a 15-day notice of
its intent to strike or engage in other work actions, including CHAOS (Create
Havoc Around Our System).&#160; In response,
on August 1, 2006, the Company filed a motion with the Bankruptcy Court seeking
to obtain an injunction against such activities.&#160; The AFA-CWA subsequently extended the strike
deadline by 10 days to August 25, 2006, in response to terrorist threats
against air travel to and within the United States.&#160; On August 17, 2006, the Bankruptcy Court
denied the Company&#146;s request for an injunction.&#160;
On August 18, 2006, the Company filed an appeal of the Bankruptcy Court&#146;s
decision with the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York (&#147;U.S. District Court&#148;). On August 25, 2006, the U.S. District Court
issued an injunction pending appeal which temporarily prevented any work action
by the AFA-CWA while the court considered the Company&#146;s appeal.&#160; The U.S. District Court reversed the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision on September 15, 2006, and granted the Company&#146;s
request for a preliminary injunction to prevent a threatened strike or work
action by the AFA-CWA.&#160; Subsequently, the
AFA-CWA appealed the U.S. District Court&#146;s ruling to the U.S. Second Circuit
Court of Appeals.&#160; Arguments related to
this matter were heard on November 28, 2006 and the appeal is pending.&#160; In addition, the Company is currently in
mediated negotiations with the AFA-CWA and representatives of the National
Mediation Board (&#147;NMB&#148;).&#160; The AFA-CWA has
requested that it be released from further negotiations by the NMB; to date the
NMB has not granted this request.&#160; A
strike or other form of self-help could have a material adverse effect on the
Company.&#160; In addition, if the Company
does not achieve the targeted level of savings under a flight attendant
agreement, the amount of labor savings achieved through its other ratified CBAs
would be subject to reduction.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-autospace:none;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On February 12, 2007, the
AFA-CWA filed a motion with the Bankruptcy Court seeking reconsideration of the
Bankruptcy Court&#146;s decision to grant the Debtors&#146; Section 1113(c) motion to
reject the Debtors&#146; CBA with the flight attendants. The Debtors believe the
motion is without merit and will oppose the AFA-CWA&#146;s motion in the Bankruptcy
Court.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">49</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='49',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has also commenced proceedings under Section 1114 of the
Bankruptcy Code, pursuant to which the Company is seeking reductions in the
costs it incurs to provide medical benefits to retirees.&#160; Negotiations with the committee formed to
represent the Company&#146;s retirees are ongoing.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Non-labor Cost Restructuring</font></i>.&#160; The
Company continues to pursue reductions in non-labor costs consistent with its
current target of $350 million in annual savings.&#160; The Company expects to realize such savings
through restructured agreements with our regional airline affiliates, reduction
in properties and facilities costs, reduced fuel burn, lower distribution,
insurance and interest costs and optimization of other contractual
relationships.&#160; The Company estimates it
has realized approximately $100 million of the targeted savings in 2006, with
the majority of the remaining savings expected to be realized in 2007.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Fleet Optimization.&#160;
</font></i>The Company
right-sized and re-optimized its fleet and network by reducing system-wide
capacity by 9.2 percent during the first year in bankruptcy.&#160; For the full year 2006, the Company reduced
its system-wide consolidated available seat miles by 7.5 percent.&#160; The Company also reached new agreements and
affirmed existing&#160; arrangements on new
aircraft as part of its fleet optimization.&#160;
The Company affirmed its deliveries of Airbus A330 aircraft and now has
one of the youngest transatlantic fleets in the industry.&#160; The Company also affirmed its position as the
North American service launch airline of the new Boeing 787 with deliveries
beginning in August 2008, and ordered 72 76-seat regional jets that will be
introduced in 2007.&#160; The dual class
regional jets are optimally sized for many domestic markets and will give the
Company potential growth opportunities over time.&#160; In addition, the Company accelerated the
retirement of the DC10 and Boeing 747-200 wide-body aircraft as well as the
Avro RJ85 fleet.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Balance Sheet Restructuring</font></i>.&#160; Under the Plan, the Company
will reduce its total pre-petition debt by approximately $4.2 billion through
the elimination of unsecured debt and restructuring of aircraft and other
secured obligations.&#160; Additionally, the
Company refinanced its Bank Term Loan with the DIP/Exit financing facility,
providing a significant interest expense savings.&#160; The aircraft restructurings will result in an
estimated $400 million reduction in ownership costs including interest, rent
and depreciation expense.&#160; The
elimination of the unsecured debt will drive an additional interest expense
reduction of approximately $150 million annually.&#160; See &#147;Note 6 &#151; Liabilities Subject to
Compromise&#148; for additional information.</p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">General Bankruptcy Matters. </font></i>&#160;As
required by the Bankruptcy Code, the United States Trustee for the Southern
District of New York appointed on September 30, 2005 an Official Committee of
Unsecured Creditors (the &#147;Creditors&#146; Committee&#148;).&#160; The Creditors&#146; Committee and its legal
representatives have a right to be heard on all matters that come before the
Bankruptcy Court concerning the reorganization.&#160;
There can be no assurance that the Creditors&#146; Committee will support the
Company&#146;s positions or plan of reorganization.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">With the exception of the
Company&#146;s non-debtor subsidiaries, the Company continues to operate its
business as &#147;debtor-in-possession&#148; under the jurisdiction of the Bankruptcy
Court and in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Bankruptcy Code,
the Federal Rules of Bankruptcy Procedure and applicable court orders.&#160; In general, as debtor-in-possession, the
Company is authorized under Chapter 11 to continue to operate as an ongoing
business, but may not engage in transactions outside the ordinary course of
business without the prior approval of the Bankruptcy Court.&#160; In conjunction with the commencement of the
Chapter 11 case, the Debtors obtained several orders from the Bankruptcy Court
that were intended to enable the Debtors to operate in the normal course of business
during the Chapter 11 case.&#160; The most
significant of these orders (i) authorize the Company to honor pre-petition
obligations to customers, (ii) authorize the Company to honor obligations to
employees for pre-petition employee salaries, wages, incentive compensation and
benefits, and (iii) permit the Debtors to operate their consolidated cash
management system during the Chapter 11 case in substantially the same manner
as it was operated prior to the commencement of the Chapter 11 case.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The bankruptcy filing
triggered defaults on substantially all the Company&#146;s debt and lease
obligations.&#160; Under Section 362 of the
Bankruptcy Code, the filing of a bankruptcy petition automatically stays most
actions against a debtor, including most actions to collect pre-petition
indebtedness or to exercise control over the property of a debtor&#146;s
estate.&#160; Absent an order of the
Bankruptcy Court, substantially all pre-petition liabilities are subject to
settlement under the plan of reorganization.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Debtors have recorded liability amounts
for the claims that can be reasonably estimated and which we believe are
probable of being allowed by the Bankruptcy Court and we have classified these
as liabilities subject to compromise in the Consolidated Balance Sheets.&#160;&#160; See &#147;Note 6 &#151; Liabilities Subject to
Compromise&#148; for additional information.&#160;
The Company expects that additional liabilities subject to compromise
will arise in the future as a result of damage claims resulting from the
rejection of certain executory contracts and unexpired leases by the
Debtors.&#160; However, the Company expects
that the assumption of certain executory contracts and unexpired leases may
convert liabilities subject to compromise to liabilities not subject to
compromise.&#160; In addition, other claims
may be recorded as a result of the Debtors claims resolution process.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Securities
Trading Matters.&#160; </font></i>On October 28, 2005, the Bankruptcy Court
entered an order that restricts the trading of the Common Stock and debt
interests in the Company.&#160; The purpose of
the order is to ensure that the Company does not lose the benefit of its net
operating loss carryforwards (&#147;NOLs&#148;) for tax purposes.&#160; Under federal and state income tax law,</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">50</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='50',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">NOLs can be used to offset future taxable income, and thus are a
valuable asset of the Debtors&#146; estate.&#160;
Certain trading in the Company&#146;s stock (or debt when the Company is in
bankruptcy) could adversely affect the Company&#146;s ability to use the NOLs.&#160; Thus, the Company obtained an order that
enables it to closely monitor certain transfers of stock and claims and
restrict those transfers that may compromise the Company&#146;s ability to use its
NOLs.&#160; See &#147;Note 12 &#151; Income Taxes&#148; for
further information related to the Company&#146;s NOLs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s Common Stock ceased trading on the NASDAQ stock market on
September 26, 2005 and now trades in the &#147;over-the-counter&#148; market under the
symbol NWACQ.PK.&#160; However, under the
Company&#146;s Plan, no value is ascribed to the Company&#146;s outstanding Common Stock,
Preferred Stock or other equity securities.&#160;
Upon the effective date of the Plan, the outstanding Common and
Preferred Stock of the Company will be cancelled for no consideration and
therefore the Company&#146;s stockholders will no longer have any interest as
stockholders in the Company by virtue of their ownership of the Company&#146;s
Common or Preferred Stock prior to emergence from bankruptcy.</font></p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The New York Stock Exchange advised the
Company on September 15, 2005 that trading in Northwest&#146;s 10.5% Class D Pass
Through Certificates, Series 2003-1 due April 1, 2009, ticker symbol NWB RP09,
as well as the 9.5% Senior Quarterly Interest Bonds due August 15, 2039
(QUIBS), ticker symbol NWB, was suspended.&#160;
The QUIBS can still be traded on the &#147;over-the-counter&#148; market under the
symbol NWBBQ.PK; however, the Company is no longer accruing or paying interest.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Request for
Equity Committee.&#160; </font></i>On or about November 22, 2006, certain equity
holders of the Debtors requested, by letter, that the United States Trustee
appoint a committee of equity security holders.&#160;
By letters dated December 26, 2006, the United States Trustee denied
this request.&#160; On January 11, 2007, an ad
hoc committee of equity security holders filed a motion in the Bankruptcy Court
seeking to compel the United States Trustee to appoint an equity committee.&#160; On February 28, 2007, the equity holders
withdrew their request to appoint an equity committee.&#160; Subsequently, they have sought the
appointment of an examiner to investigate the Company&#146;s plans regarding
industry consolidation.&#160; The Debtors do
not believe this request is appropriate, and will oppose it in the Bankruptcy
Court.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 2&#151;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</font></b></p>

<p align="left" style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Financial Statement Presentation:&#160; </font></i>The Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements have been prepared in
accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (&#147;GAAP&#148;) on a going
concern basis, which contemplates the realization of assets and the
satisfaction of liabilities in the normal course of business. Accordingly, our
consolidated financial statements do not include any adjustments relating to
the recoverability of assets and classification of liabilities that might be
necessary should we be unable to continue as a going concern.&#160; Due to our Chapter 11 proceedings, the
realization of assets and the satisfaction of liabilities, without substantial
adjustments and/or changes in ownership, are subject to uncertainty, and
accordingly, there is substantial doubt about the current financial reporting
entity&#146;s ability to continue as a going concern.&#160; Upon emergence from bankruptcy, we expect to
adopt fresh start reporting in accordance with the American Institute of
Certified Public Accountants Statement of Position 90-7,<i> Financial Reporting by Entities in Reorganization
under the Bankruptcy Code</i> (&#147;SOP 90-7&#148;), which will result in our
becoming a new entity for financial reporting purposes.&#160; The adoption of fresh start reporting will
have a material impact on the consolidated financial statements of the new
financial reporting entity.</p>

<p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-align:left;text-indent:18.0pt;text-justify:inter-ideograph;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The accompanying consolidated financial statements have been prepared in
accordance with SOP 90-7, and on a going concern basis, which contemplates
continuity of operations, realization of assets and liquidation of
post-petition liabilities in the ordinary course of business.&#160; In accordance with SOP 90-7, the financial
statements for the periods presented distinguish transactions and events that
are directly associated with the reorganization from the ongoing operations of
the Company.&#160; While operating as
debtors-in-possession under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code
and subject to approval of the Bankruptcy Court or otherwise as permitted in
the ordinary course of business, the Debtors may sell or otherwise dispose of
assets, or liquidate and settle liabilities, for some amounts other than those
reflected in the consolidated financial statements</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Business:</font></i>&#160; Northwest&#146;s operations account
for approximately 98% of the Company&#146;s consolidated operating revenues and
expenses.&#160; Northwest is a major air
carrier engaged principally in the commercial transportation of passengers and
cargo, directly serving more than 240 cities in 26 countries in North America,
Asia and Europe.&#160; Northwest&#146;s global
airline network includes domestic hubs at Detroit, Minneapolis/St. Paul and
Memphis, an extensive Pacific route system with a hub in Tokyo, a transatlantic
joint venture with KLM, which operates through a hub in Amsterdam, a domestic
and international alliance with Continental and Delta, membership in SkyTeam, a
global airlines alliance with KLM, Continental, Delta, Air France, Alitalia,
Aerom&#233;xico, CSA Czech Airlines, Korean Air and Aeroflot, exclusive marketing
agreements with three domestic regional carriers, Pinnacle Airlines and Mesaba,
both of which currently operate as Northwest Airlink carriers, and Compass
which will operate as Northwest Airlink, and a cargo business that includes a
dedicated fleet of freighter aircraft that operate through hubs in Anchorage
and Tokyo.</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">51</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='51',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Basis of Consolidation:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; NWA Corp. is a holding company whose
principal indirect operating subsidiary is Northwest.&#160; The consolidated financial statements include
the accounts of NWA Corp. and all consolidated subsidiaries.&#160; All significant intercompany transactions
have been eliminated.&#160; Investments in 20%
to 50% owned companies, as well as Pinnacle Airlines, are accounted for by the
equity method.&#160; Other investments are
accounted for by the cost method.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">Certain prior year amounts have been reclassified to conform
to the current year financial statement presentation.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Cash and Cash Equivalents: </font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160;Cash equivalents are carried at cost and consist
primarily of cash and unrestricted money market funds.&#160; These highly liquid instruments approximate
fair value due to their short maturities.&#160;
The Company classifies investments with a maturity of more than three
months as short-term investments.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Restricted Cash:</font></i>&nbsp; During 2006 the restricted cash balance
decreased $176 million to $424 million as of December 31, 2006 from $600
million as of December 31, 2005.&#160; The
decrease was primarily due to a $153 million decrease in a receivables
financing required cash collateral balance, a $6 million decrease in the
Company&#146;s irrevocable trust fund balance and a $17 million decrease in other
restricted cash items.&#160; As a result of
the Company filing for bankruptcy, a receivables financing required the Company
to establish a cash collateral account, the balance of which was $153 million
as of December 31, 2005.&#160; As a result of
restructuring the receivables financing with the lender, the need for this
account was eliminated and the balance was reclassified to unrestricted
cash.&#160; The Company in the ordinary course
of business collects funds from passengers and withholdings from employees that
are required to be paid to various taxing authorities, in addition to certain
taxes that are self assessed.&nbsp; These collections include U.S.
transportation taxes, passenger facility charges, and fuel taxes, which are
collected in the capacity of an agent and are presented on a net basis.&#160; Withholdings include the employee portion of
payroll taxes, among others.&nbsp; The Company established an irrevocable trust
in 2002 and since then has made regular deposits to the trust from which
payments are issued to the taxing authorities.</p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Use of Estimates:&#160; </font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">The
preparation of consolidated financial statements in conformity with GAAP
requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts
reported in its consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes.&#160; Actual results could differ from those
estimates.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Operating Revenues: </font></i>&#160;Passenger and cargo revenues are
recognized when the transportation is provided, or when the ticket expires, or
is expected to expire, unused.&#160; The main
component of air traffic liability represents the estimated value of sold but
unused tickets.&#160; The Company regularly
performs evaluations of unused tickets.&#160;
Unused tickets are recognized in passenger revenue based on current
estimates, along with adjustments resulting from revisions of previous
estimates.&#160; These adjustments relate
primarily to ticket usage patterns, refunds, exchanges, inter-airline transactions,
and other travel obligations for which final settlement occurs in periods
subsequent to the sale of the related tickets at amounts other than the
original sales price.&#160; While these
factors generally follow predictable patterns that provide a reliable basis for
estimating the air traffic liability, and the Company uses historical trends
and averages in its estimates, significant changes in business conditions
and/or passenger behavior that affect these estimates could have a significant
impact on the consolidated financial statements.&#160; Other revenues include MLT, transportation
fees and charter revenues, and are recognized when the service or
transportation is provided.</p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Property, Equipment and Depreciation:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; Owned property and equipment are stated at cost.&#160; Property and equipment acquired under capital
leases are stated at the lower of the present value of minimum lease payments
or fair market value at the inception of the lease.&#160; Property and equipment are depreciated to
residual values using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives
of the assets, which generally range from four to 25 years for flight equipment
and three to 32 years for other property and equipment.&#160; Leasehold improvements are generally
amortized over the remaining period of the lease or the estimated service life
of the related asset, whichever is less.&#160;
Property and equipment under capital leases are amortized over the lease
terms or the estimated useful lives of the assets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company accounts for certain airport leases under the EITF Issue No.
99-13<i>, Application of EITF Issue No. 97-10, The Effect
of Lessee Involvement in Asset Construction, and FASB Interpretation No. 23,
Leases of Certain Property Owned by a Governmental Unit or Authority to
Entities that Enter into Leases with Governmental Entities</i>, which
requires the financing related to certain guaranteed airport construction
projects committed to after September 23, 1999, be recorded on the balance
sheet.&#160; Capitalized expenditures of
$234.9 million at December 31, 2006 that relate to airport improvements at
Minneapolis/St. Paul, Memphis, Knoxville and Seattle are recorded in other
property and equipment, with the corresponding obligations included in
liabilities subject to compromise.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">52</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='52',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Impairment of Long-Lived Assets:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; The Company evaluates long-lived assets for
potential impairments in compliance with SFAS No. 144, <i>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of
Long-Lived Assets</i>, (&#147;SFAS No. 144)<i>.&#160; </i>These impairment evaluations are primarily initiated by fleet plan changes
and therefore predominantly performed on fleet-related assets.&#160; The Company records impairment losses on
long-lived assets when events and circumstances indicate the assets might be
impaired and the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those
assets are less than their carrying amounts.&#160;
Impairment losses are measured by comparing the fair value of the assets
to their carrying amounts.&#160; In
determining the need to record impairment charges, the Company is required to
make certain estimates regarding such things as the current fair market value
of the assets and future net cash flows to be generated by the assets.&#160; The current fair market value is determined
by independent appraisal or published sales values of similar assets, and the
future net cash flows are based on assumptions such as asset utilization,
expected remaining useful lives, future market trends and projected salvage
values.&#160; Impairment charges are recorded
in depreciation and amortization or reorganization expense on the Company&#146;s
Consolidated Statements of Operations.&#160;
If there are subsequent changes in these estimates, or if actual results
differ from these estimates, additional impairment charges may be recognized.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">In the fourth quarter 2006, the Company recorded $33.5 million
as additional reorganization expense for the impairment of certain Boeing
747-200 passenger and freighter aircraft and DC9-30 aircraft.&#160; See &#147;Note 5 &#151; Reorganization Related Items.&#148;&#160; The Company also recorded an aircraft
impairment of $5.8 million as additional depreciation expense for one DC9-30.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">In the second quarter of 2006, the Company recorded $28
million related to the impairment of six owned aircraft and related inventory
and equipment, which were permanently removed from service.&#160; These charges reflect the Company&#146;s decision
to accelerate the retirement of its DC10 aircraft and to permanently park three
DC9 aircraft.&#160; The impairment charges
were recorded as reorganization expenses and are included in &#147;Note 5 &#151;
Reorganization Related Items.&#148;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2005, as part of the implementation of its restructuring
driven fleet plan, the Company removed 18 DC9-30 aircraft from operations and
determined that the Avro RJ85 fleet would be removed from service by the end of
2006.&#160; As a result, the Company recorded,
as reorganization expense, impairment charges of $153 million for the DC9-30
aircraft and the 10 owned Avro RJ85 aircraft in the fourth quarter of 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2005, the Company recorded $48 million for the impairment and
other charges related to nine owned and two leased aircraft of various types
that it did not intend to return to service.&#160;
Of the $48 million recorded, approximately $40 million related to
acceleration of aircraft rent expense and other charges on the two leased
aircraft and $8 million was attributable to aircraft impairments on the nine
owned aircraft.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2004, as part of a revised fleet plan, the Company determined
that it did not intend to return to service 10 Boeing 747-200 passenger
aircraft that had been temporarily removed from operations.&#160; As a result, the Company recorded, as
additional depreciation expense, impairment charges of $104 million associated
with these aircraft and related inventory in the second quarter of 2004.&#160; In December 2004, additional impairment charges
of $99 million were recorded in conjunction with a new aircraft order and the
related early retirement of certain DC10-30 aircraft, and the accelerated
retirement of the Company&#146;s DC9-10 fleet, as part of a revised fleet plan.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Flight Equipment Spare Parts:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; Flight equipment spare parts are carried at
lower of average cost or market and are expensed when consumed in
operations.&#160; An allowance for
depreciation is provided at rates that depreciate cost, less residual value,
over the estimated useful lives of the related aircraft.&#160; Inventory sales at amounts greater or less
than their carried values are recorded as an adjustment to the allowance for
depreciation and therefore do not generate gain or loss recognition for income
statement purposes.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Airframe and Engine Maintenance:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; Routine maintenance, airframe and engine
overhauls are charged to expense as incurred or accrued when a contractual
obligation exits, such as induction of an asset at a vendor for service or on
the basis of hours flown for certain costs covered by power-by-the-hour type
agreements.&nbsp; Modifications that enhance the operating performance or
extend the useful lives of airframes or engines are capitalized and amortized
over the remaining estimated useful life of the asset.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">International Routes:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; Certain of the Company&#146;s international routes
result from the U.S.-Japan bilateral aviation agreement, which establishes
rights to carry traffic between Japan and the U.S., and extensive &#147;fifth
freedom&#148; rights from Japan to India, the South Pacific and other Asian
destinations.&#160; Fifth freedom rights allow
Northwest to operate service from any gateway in Japan to points beyond Japan
and carry Japanese originating passengers. These rights have no termination date,
and the Company has the supporting infrastructure (airport gates, slots and
terminal facility leases) in place to operate air service to Japan from its
U.S. hub and gateway airports indefinitely.&#160;
In accordance with SFAS No. 142, <i>Goodwill
and Other Intangible Assets, </i>the Company does not amortize these
intangible assets, but instead tests the balance for impairment annually and/or
when an impairment indicator exists.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Frequent Flyer Program</font></i>:&#160;
Northwest operates a frequent flyer loyalty program known as &#147;WorldPerks.&#148;&#160; WorldPerks is designed to retain and increase
traveler loyalty by offering incentives for their continued patronage.&#160; Under the WorldPerks</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">53</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='53',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">program, miles are earned by flying on Northwest or
its alliance partners and by using the services of program partners for such
things as credit card use, hotel stays, car rentals and other activities.&#160; Northwest sells mileage credits to the
program partners.&#160; WorldPerks members
accumulate mileage in their accounts and later redeem mileage for free or
upgraded travel on Northwest and other participating airlines.&#160; WorldPerks members that achieve certain
mileage thresholds also receive enhanced service benefits from Northwest like
special service lines, advance flight boarding and upgrades.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company utilizes a number of estimates in
accounting for its WorldPerks frequent flyer program.&#160; The Company accounts for the frequent flyer
program obligations by recording a liability for the estimated incremental cost
of flight awards expected to be redeemed on Northwest and other airline
partners.&#160; Customers are expected to
redeem their mileage, and a liability is recorded, when their accounts
accumulate the minimum number of miles needed to obtain one flight award.&#160; Additional assumptions are made, based on
past customer behavior, regarding the likelihood of customers using the miles
for first-class upgrades or other premiums instead of flight awards, the
expected use on other airline partners, as well as the likelihood of customers
never redeeming the miles.&#160; Estimated
incremental costs of carrying a passenger flying on redeemed miles on Northwest
are based on the system average cost per passenger for food and beverage, fuel,
insurance, security, miscellaneous claims and WorldPerks distribution and
administration expenses.&#160; Estimated
incremental cost for carriage on airline partners is based on contractual
rates.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The estimated liability excludes accounts
that have never attained the minimum travel award level, awards that are
expected to be redeemed for upgrades, and the proportion not expected to be
redeemed at all, but includes an estimate for partially earned awards on
accounts that previously earned an award.&#160;
In December 2004, Northwest revised its estimates associated with (i)
the future mix of redemptions involving reciprocal frequent flyer programs with
other airlines; (ii) incremental costs per type of award redemption; and (iii)
the likelihood of customers never redeeming their award miles. For certain
reciprocal frequent flyer programs, Northwest does not record a liability for
the gross payments to other airlines for WorldPerks members&#146; redemption travel
until the Company meets certain contractual thresholds that are required prior
to making cash payments. For other reciprocal frequent flyer arrangements with
no such contractual thresholds, Northwest records a liability for the gross
payments it expects to make for WorldPerks members&#146; redemption travel on the
other airlines, without regard to the payments the Company expects to receive
for their frequent flyer members&#146; redemption travel on Northwest.&#160; These changes in estimates resulted in a
liability increase of $77 million, due primarily to the higher cost of awards
redeemed on reciprocal frequent flyer programs versus Northwest&#146;s incremental
cost for carriage, partially offset by a higher projection of unused award
miles.&#160; While the average cost of an
award increased as a result of these revised estimates, the total number of
awards expected to be redeemed declined substantially.&#160; The number of estimated travel awards
outstanding and expected to be redeemed at December 31, 2006, 2005, and 2004
was approximately 3.6, 3.6, and 3.8 million, respectively. Northwest recorded a
liability for these estimated awards of $269 million, $248 million, and $215
million at December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The number of travel awards used for travel
on Northwest and Airlink operations during the years ended December 31, 2006,
2005 and 2004 was approximately 1,491,000, 1,492,000 and 1,380,000,
representing an estimated 7.3%, 7.3%, and 6.9% of total RPMs for each such
year, respectively.&#160; Including travel
allowed on Northwest, Airlink and alliance partner airlines, travel awards
represented an estimated 9.3%, 8.9%, and 8.5% of system-wide consolidated RPMs
for December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 respectively.&#160; Northwest believes displacement of revenue
passengers is minimal based on the low ratio of WorldPerks award usage to
revenue passenger miles and the Company&#146;s ability to manage frequent flyer
inventory through seat allocations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company also sells mileage credits to
participating partners such as credit card issuers, hotels, long-distance
companies, car rental firms, partner airlines, and other partners.&#160; This revenue, a portion of which is deferred,
is recognized in passenger revenue.&#160; The
deferred revenue is recognized over a 24 month period in which the credits are
expected to be redeemed for travel.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Advertising:&#160; </font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">Advertising
costs, included in selling and marketing expenses, are expensed as incurred and
were $62 million, $63 million, and $72 million in 2006, 2005, and 2004,
respectively.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Stock Based Compensation:&#160; </font></i>As of December 31, 2006, the Company maintains
stock incentive plans for officers and key employees of the Company (the &#147;Management
Plans&#148;) and a stock option plan for pilot employees (the &#147;Pilot Plan&#148;).&#160; See &#147;Note 10 &#151; Stock Based Compensation&#148; for
additional discussion of stock based compensation.&#160;&#160;&#160; The
Company adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (Revised 2004), <i>Share-Based Payment</i> (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;123R&#148;), using the
modified-prospective transition method, effective January&nbsp;1, 2006.&#160; In addition to requiring supplemental
disclosures, SFAS No.&nbsp;123R eliminated the option to apply the intrinsic
value measurement provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25, <i>Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees</i> (&#147;APB No. 25&#148;), to
stock compensation awards issued to employees.&#160;
Furthermore, the Statement required the Company to recognize
compensation cost for the portion of outstanding awards previously accounted
for under the provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25 for which the requisite service had
not been rendered as of the adoption date for this Statement.&#160; Because the Company voluntarily adopted the
fair value method prescribed by SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <i>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</i> (&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;123&#148;)
using the prospective method, effective January&nbsp;1, 2003, the unvested
awards still accounted for under the provisions of APB No.&nbsp;25, and
therefore subject to the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R, were minimal.&#160; The Statement also required the Company to
estimate forfeitures of stock compensation awards as of the grant</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">54</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='54',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">date of the award.&#160;
The Company&#146;s previous policy was to recognize forfeitures as they
occurred, and the required adjustment to estimate forfeitures as of the grant
date of the award for outstanding awards that were not fully vested as of
December 31, 2005 was immaterial.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Foreign Currency:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; Assets and liabilities denominated in foreign
currency are remeasured at current exchange rates with resulting gains and
losses generally included in net income.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Deferred Tax Assets:</font></i><font color="black" style="color:windowtext;">&#160; The Company accounts for income taxes
utilizing the liability method.&#160; Deferred
income taxes are primarily recorded to reflect the tax consequences of
differences between the tax and financial reporting bases of assets and
liabilities.&#160; Under the provisions of
SFAS No. 109, <i>Accounting for Income Taxes </i>(&#147;SFAS No. 109&#148;), the realization of
the future tax benefits of a deferred tax asset is dependent on future taxable
income against which such tax benefits can be applied.&#160; All available evidence must be considered in
the determination of whether sufficient future taxable income will exist.&#160; Such evidence includes, but is not limited
to, the company&#146;s financial performance, the market environment in which the
company operates, the utilization of past tax credits, and the length of
relevant carryback and carryforward periods.&#160;
Sufficient negative evidence, such as cumulative net losses during a
three-year period that includes the current year and the prior two years, may
require that a valuation allowance be established with respect to existing and
future deferred tax assets.&#160; As a result,
it is more likely than not that future deferred tax assets will require a
valuation allowance to be recorded to fully reserve against the uncertainty
that those assets would be realized.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">New Accounting Standards:</font></i>&#160; In September 2006, the FASB
issued SFAS No. 158, which amends SFAS No. 87 and SFAS No. 106,<i> Employers&#146; Accounting for Postretirement Benefits
Other Than Pensions </i>(&#147;SFAS No. 106&#148;) to require recognition of the
overfunded or underfunded status of pension and other postretirement benefit
plans on the balance sheet. Under SFAS No. 158, gains and losses, prior service
costs and credits, and any remaining transition amounts under SFAS No. 87 and
SFAS No. 106 that have not yet been recognized through net periodic&nbsp;benefit
cost will be recognized in accumulated other comprehensive income, net of tax
effects. The measurement date, the date at which the benefit obligation and
plan assets are measured, is required to be the company&#146;s fiscal year end. The
Company previously utilized a fiscal year-end measurement date.&#160; SFAS No. 158 is effective for publicly-held
companies for fiscal years ending after December 15, 2006, except for the
measurement date provisions, which are effective for fiscal years ending after
December 15, 2008. The adoption of SFAS No. 158 increased the Company&#146;s
long-term pension and other postretirement benefit liabilities, as well as the
Company&#146;s equity deficit by $224 million. SFAS No. 158 does not affect the
results of operations.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;157, <i>Fair Value Measurements </i>(&#147;SFAS
No.&nbsp;157&#148;). This Statement provides a single definition of fair value, a
framework for measuring fair value, and expanded disclosures concerning fair
value.&#160; Previously, different definitions
of fair value were contained in various accounting pronouncements creating
inconsistencies in measurement and disclosures. SFAS No.&nbsp;157 applies to
those previously issued pronouncements that prescribe fair value as the
relevant measure of value, except SFAS No.&nbsp;123
(Revised 2004), <i>Share-Based Payment</i>
(&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;123R&#148;) and related interpretations and pronouncements
that require or permit measurement similar to fair value but are not intended
to measure fair value. This pronouncement is effective for fiscal years
beginning after November&nbsp;15, 2007. The Company is currently evaluating the
impact of adopting SFAS No. 157 on its financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In September&nbsp;2006, the
SEC Office of the Chief Accountant and Divisions of Corporation Finance and
Investment Management released SAB No.&nbsp;108, <i>Considering the Effects of Prior Year Misstatements when Quantifying
Misstatements in Current Year Financial Statements </i>(&#147;SAB
No.&nbsp;108&#148;), which provides interpretive guidance on how the effects of the
carryover or reversal of prior year misstatements should be considered in
quantifying a current year misstatement. The SEC staff believes that
registrants should quantify errors using both a balance sheet and an income
statement approach and evaluate whether either approach results in quantifying
a misstatement that, when all relevant quantitative and qualitative factors are
considered, is material. This pronouncement is effective for fiscal years
ending after November&nbsp;15, 2006. The Company will adopt SAB No.&nbsp;108
effective the beginning of 2007. The adoption of SAB No.&nbsp;108 is not
expected to have a material impact on the Company&#146;s financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In June 2006, the FASB issued Interpretation No. 48, <i>Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes </i>(&#147;FIN
48&#148;), which clarifies FASB Statement No. 109, <i>Accounting
for Income Taxes</i>.&#160; FIN 48
prescribes a consistent recognition threshold and criteria for measurement of
uncertain tax positions for financial statement purposes.&#160; FIN 48 requires the financial statement
recognition of an income tax benefit when the Company determines that it is &#147;more
likely than not&#148; the tax position will be ultimately sustained.&#160; FIN 48 also requires expanded disclosure with
respect to the uncertainty in income taxes.&#160;
The Company will adopt FIN 48 as of January 1, 2007, and is currently
assessing the impact of FIN 48 on its consolidated financial statements.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">55</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='55',FILE='C:\fc\74145555571_H10056_1873074\5449-1-fk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 14:55 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-36.0pt;"><b><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 3&#151;Change in Accounting for Certain Pension Plan Administrative
Expenses</font></b></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">During the second quarter of
2005, the Company changed its method of recognizing certain pension plan
administrative expenses associated with the Company&#146;s defined benefit pension
plans and now includes them as a service cost component of net periodic pension
cost.&#160; These expenses include trustee
fees, other administrative expenses and insurance premiums paid to the Pension
Benefit Guaranty Corporation (&#147;PBGC&#148;), all of which previously were reflected
as a reduction in the market value of plan assets and therefore amortized with
other asset gains and losses.&#160; The
Company believes this change is preferable because it more appropriately
ascribes the expenses to the period in which they are incurred.&#160; The cumulative effect of applying this change
to net periodic pension expense in prior years was $69.1 million, which was
retroactively recorded as of January&nbsp;1, 2005, and was included in the
Company&#146;s Consolidated Statements of Operations for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2005.&#160; The impact of
this change on the year ended December 31, 2005, was an increase in net
periodic benefit cost of $37.7 million.</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">The
following table illustrates pro forma amounts as of December 31, assuming the
new accounting method is applied retroactively:</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="color:red;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><b><font size="2" color="black" face="Times New Roman" style="color:windowtext;font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 4&#151;Earnings (Loss) Per Share Data</font></b></p>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(10.32</font></p>

  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 2.25pt 0pt;width:.82%;">

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>For the twelve months ended December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, 19.1
million, 19.3 million and 19.8 million incremental shares related to dilutive
securities, respectively, were not included in the diluted earnings per share
calculation because the Company reported a net loss for these periods.&#160;&#160; Incremental shares related to dilutive
securities have an anti-dilutive impact on earnings per share when a net loss
is reported and therefore are not included in the calculation.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additionally,
6.2 million, 6.3 million and 6.5 million shares of Series C Preferred Stock
were excluded from the effect of dilutive securities for the years ended
December 31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, because the Company reported a
net loss for these periods and the inclusion of these shares would have had an
anti-dilutive effect on the earnings per share calculation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
dilutive securities do not include 7.4 million, 7.9 million and 1.3 million
employee stock options and restricted shares for the years ended December 31,
2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, because the exercise prices of these options
were greater than the average market price of the Common Stock for the period
or the amount of assumed proceeds for the restricted shares did not result in
incremental dilutive shares under the treasury method.&#160; Total employee stock options and restricted
shares outstanding of 7.4 million, 7.9 million and 9.4 million as of December
31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively, were not included in diluted securities
because the Company reported a net loss for the years ended December 31, 2006,
2005 and 2004.</font></p>

<h1 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Note 5&#151;Reorganization Related Items</font></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance
with SOP 90-7 and on a going concern basis that contemplates continuity of
operations, realization of assets, and liquidation of post-petition liabilities
in the ordinary course of business.&#160; In
accordance with SOP 90-7, the financial statements for the periods presented
distinguish transactions and events that are directly associated with the reorganization
from the ongoing operations of the Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Reorganization items recorded during the twelve months ended December
31, 2006, largely consisted of aircraft restructurings, employee claims,
pension plan curtailment charges, rejection charges, professional fees, and
aircraft impairment charges.&#160; The charges
for restructuring aircraft leases/debt are primarily non-cash costs that
include the estimated claims resulting from the Company&#146;s renegotiation of
certain aircraft obligations.&#160; The
employee claims resulted from negotiations associated with the Company&#146;s
implementation of new contract terms with ALPA, the IAM, ATSA, TWU</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">57</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='57',FILE='C:\Fc\74122617436_P66111CHE_1868503\5449-1-fm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 15 12:26 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">and
NAMA.&#160; The pension plan curtailment
charges are non-cash costs associated with the freezing of the ALPA and
contract pension plans.&#160; Aircraft
rejection charges are non-cash costs that include the estimated allowable
claims, net of gains on the sale and/or settlement of residual value
guarantees, resulting from the Company&#146;s rejection of certain aircraft leases
and/or return of aircraft as part of the bankruptcy process.&#160; These claims remain subject to future
adjustments arising from negotiated settlements, actions of the Bankruptcy
Court, the determination as to the value of any collateral securing claims,
proofs of claim or other events.&#160; The
charges for professional fees include only those professional fees related to
the bankruptcy process.&#160; Aircraft
impairment charges are non-cash write-downs of owned aircraft that were
rejected or permanently grounded as part of the Company&#146;s fleet restructuring.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition to the charges disclosed above, reorganization items for the
twelve months ended December 31, 2005, included debt and lease valuation
adjustments.&#160; Debt and lease valuation
adjustments represent one time non-cash charges related to the write-off of
issuance costs, and discounts related to the Company&#146;s debt and leases
classified as liabilities subject to compromise.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;text-indent:13.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Net reorganization items, as shown on the Consolidated Statement of
Operations, consist of the following:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">
